reviewText:
Early Access Review

War! Not a battle, not some skirmish ...war.
That is what you engage in with this game.
You do not move a few units here and there, you move armies!
You dont stop with a few building and call it good, you rise up bases across the map.
Here territory means resources as the reverse should also be true!
In this game STRATEGY CONQUERS ALL!

The game has nice graphics. watching the enemy line be atomised by heavy laser fir from my titan advance is all so enticing and encites me to continue the advance if only to see more battle.
i have notice a rathe large amount of problems regarding to issuing commands however now with the beta release many of those problems have been dealt with so i guess the devs had seen them too.
the gameplay in of itself is rather simple, no real need to learn alot in order to play if you can handle any RTS you can handle this (YOUR STRATEGY MAY BE ANOTHER STORY).

I mentioned controlling armies opposed to units and while yes the units make the army you will find that sending 200 units to act as a mobile wall, with another 100 or so as cannon fodder to delay a point being taken on the other side of the map,  an air strike force circling around all of that in the numbers of another 100 or so and one more massive push straight through the enemy center with 500 units... may in fact not even be late game. with six players that may indeed be early game.
Numbers can help you win any engagement, but... it is the proper use of those numbers that in the end will see you victorious.
You might be wondering well how many units can i control?" to this dont have an exact.
before the latest patch (and i havent yet seen anything to tell me different) after winning the game with a logistics cap of 3000+ (should be noted the titans which are your bigest units only cost around 30 logistics) i had decided to continue the game and push my research to answer the question of just how many can be at my call... I reached 105
date: 000 before i quit knowing that such numbers in a real game would be absurd but yet even as i pressed the EXIT button still there was reserarch to do and higher numbers to obtain.\n\nAll in all the scope of this game is fantasic
recommended:
i cant wait for the finishing touches to be applyed.
once again stardock has not disappointed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm an old school RTS gamer back from the first of the genre, overall gamer much longer than that. When I first saw this game, I honestly didn't like it, thought it looked generic and had little to offer. I'm always a sucker for these types of games, sooner or later I knew I would buy it, here are some of my thoughts:

Updated 5 March 2016:

Positives:
-Game has developed nicely since the latest Beta 2 patch, great work on the dreadnoughts and adding variation and depth for some of the key units
-Large variety of maps
-DX12
-Unit artwork and overall design are interesting and highly detailed - cutting edge
-Various classes of units, all have a unique purpose, some say you just cluster them together and attack, they would be missing out on the beauty of joint operations and combined firepower, using spotters and long range shooters etc.
-Orbital powers and unique game changing elements, this aspect has improved more so since the latest update
-Maps are well laid out and offer something unique to each, fit the game design well
-Sound is refreshing and exceptional, at first I was disappointed that there was no voice for each unit, though currently their sound is unique and distinctive, makes sense, the sound in this game is really good. The sound effects have improved tremendously since the last update
-Gameplay is fantastic, the AI in skirmish is already very competent and likely only going to get better, definitely already a strong aspect of this game, it’s really good for SP players
-Good use of recon drones and medic units - well implemented
-Great Development team, very similar approach to Eugen Systems, they have a love for this game and it shows, they are awesome and interact with the players often and are always looking to improve aspects of the game
-Reminds me of SUPCOM to a degree - with improved graphics and significantly better sound effects
-I'm using a i7-920 stock, Gigabyte G1 Gaming 970, 12GB Ram, Win10 and I'm able to play with every setting maxed at 2K, no issues at all.


Negatives:
-Still some rough edges, though I expect them to be ironed out, more so polishing, this is to be expected given its in Beta 2
-No other types of units beyond hover, though I have to admit the hover units are working much better in game than I expected, this was something I was worried about, would still like to see tracked, wheeled, walkers, mechs etc. in the game at some point
-Only two factions, would have like to have had three
-Would like to see each faction have about five more units prior to final release
-Ability to interact with skirmish AI partners would be awesome to see, go here, defend this spot, please assist me, focus on this area, attack, please help now, the type of unit communications in SUPCOM, C&C, AOE and other RTS games

I will add and change to this review as the game progresses, though to keep things simple, if you are an RTS fan or enjoy strategy gaming in general, grab this game.  As you play more the game grows on you fast, there are a lot of tactics to be employed, this is easily one of the best RTS games to come out in years. I can only imagine how much more improved its going to be by launch, in its current condition, I would easily give it a 8.0 out of 10, with the score getting higher as more things are added. I highly recommend Ashes of the Singularity; it has a chance to become an all-time RTS classic.

reviewText:
The game is combination of total annihilation, starcraft, company of heroes, and supreme commander.

Pros:
+ All units have a purpose, and are not deposed by a tier 2 or tier 3 equivalent
+ Maps are well designed, with height, unit speed, and distance from home base playing major roles in strategy
+ Smart AI
+ Reasonably differentiated two factions
+ You can win by victory points or conquest which creates additional strategies
+ Regions, which allows for choke points and can punish over aggresive expansion (similar to company of heroes, sins of a solar empire).

Cons
- No water units (supposedly coming in expansion)
- Can not airlift units
- Limited tech tree (you can pretty much build everything immediatly), which can be harder for beginner players to understand what they should be building and what they shouldn't
- Poor UI for T3 units when figuring out upgrades

Summary:  I find my greivances to be minor.  I have enjoyed my skirmeshes with the AI (I believe I played on Challenging most times), but have not ventured online because my internet is slow (~2 mbits/sec).  Its easily the most fun I have had playing a real time strategy game since Sins of a solar Empire or Company of Heroes (the first one).

reviewText:
Ashes of the Singularity is a real-time strategy (RTS) game at an epic scale based in the far future.

What is Great about this game:

- Very strong RTS game mechanics with solid tactical and strategic elements
- An elegant combination of various other great RTS games (Supreme Commander, Company of Heroes, etc) but still with an authentic flavor of its own
- Incredible replayability and playstyle variety - particularly in skirmish mode
- The unit management for such a large-scale game is second to none.  Put units into an army, and they simply work smartly together.  No micromanagement!
- Micromanagement is at a minimal level for a game of this scale.  Armies are generally smart enough (assuming decent unit composition) to actually follow orders and execute on them relatively well
- The games visuals and tech are amazing.  The Nitous engine (which is what this game runs on) is a beauty and looks so lovely that I switched graphics cards to run it better

What is Good about this game:

- Good unit variety with excellent hard counters (e.g. Apollo > Bomber > Zeus > Apollo across several different combinations of units etc)
- Dreadnoughts look and play amazingly - good depth and satisfaction to their upgrade tree, just fun to watch blow stuff up
- There is almost unlimited skill-ceiling even against the AI as the skirmish AI is quite excellent
- A good game of skirmish can feel epic and still be done in 30-60 minutes

What could be improved in this game:

- Some of the controls can be a little fiddly:
- Very large groups of units don't form armies entirely well (e.g. perpetually having the option to group into an army even after you just gave that command)
- If an army loses its lead" unit (i.e. the biggest highest level unit)
date: the army appears to forget all its orders and ungroups\n- Sometimes giving simple capture node orders simply won't work
recommended: and you have to target either around the node or click many times which can be frustrating\n- The dreadnaught upgrades can be a little tedious on very large maps.  Would be nice if there was an icon in the GUI similar to the idle engineer icon to simply auto-find them and select them to upgrade faster with less hunting

votesTotal:
etc)
- The AI can be tough even at lower difficulties until you learn the game pretty well
- Would love more large skirmish maps
- The story and campaign are lacking

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First Glance Day 1 Review:
I love observing the two sides of the coin, to get a feel for what the coin represents. On the positive side you can see ppl clamouring the revival of the great epic scale RTSes, on the negative side you see people clamouring on how poorly it is built in the general comparison sense to other RTSes.

Now here's my take on it:
This is a game that is meant to be a MacroRTS based gameplay. Sure you have no differences whatsoever in terms of zooming in and out as functionality for such fidelity per unit but then again, you can just press space and hop to the focused event.

The moment I start the game I am already heading to the macro based gameplay where CROSS MAP APM matters more than micromap APM. See this is what kills it for half of the RTS fans who are all in the negative review camp for this game. You can't deflect, counter, micromanage your way out of a swarm of brutes and dreadnaughts that have the range of an entire sector, but you can call for orbital help. If your units are out of position, they take a long time to reinforce a position then your entirely screwed. This means having preemptive tactics, preemptive strikes, flanking and macromanaging are your go to skills for this game. To some (infact many modern RTS players who were born in the microRTS golden era), this is a severe let down.

Back in those days, to those who were lucky enough to be born in the age of total anihhilation enjoying the thrill during its peak time, collosal battles across the map, 5 maybe 20 divisions of units engaging at a time on multiple fronts was a thing, no, it was THE THING! Total Annihilation swept the best game of all time for decades! It gave casual players means to learn and play since macroplay is very forgiving and gradual, unlike MicroRTS where scaling and the snowballing effect is rampant.

We MacroRTS ppl love to give others a shot on the same playing field, on the same mindset of casual/slow pace but enthralling climb to the epic end on a static but functional playing field with a plethora of self made objectives". MicroRTS doesn't give you this feeling. It almost always counts on TrueAPM

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Here goes my review:

Pros:   Exceptional stunning graphics  (ultra quality settings)
A mix of map sizes from huge to tiny --> well suited for the variation of number of friends online
Music is awesome so as sound effects  (some of the sounds reminds me of Starcraft |o|)
Gameplay is balanced up to now  (although we need a few more factions/races to choose from)
Price is acceptable --> considering this is a RTS game of next generation --> lots of replay value

Compare this game to its competitors:

Grey Goo --- Perhaps slightly better UI --- significantly less content
Planetary Annilation -- graphics are not comparable to Ashes of Singularity -- large scaled battle is similar
Act of Aggression -- different theme -- comparable graphics -- smaller scale

Cons:  none of yet

Recommendation:

If you love Sins of a Solar Empire (one of my all time favourite), get this game - 200% satisfaction.

If you are economical, wait for the Steam summer sale - tones of money saved.

If you want more stuff (units, etc.) post it in the discussion forum.

Titles I played:  Company of Heroes 2, Sins of a Solar Empire, Command and Conquer Generals - Zero Hour, StarCraft II, Age of Empires III, Act of Aggression/Grey Goo/Planetary Annilation (at friend's house).

I will update my review with respect to the maturation of this game.

reviewText:
Pros of the game:

1. Great underlying technology making the game future proof: DX12, multi GPU support, fully utilizes my multicore system.
2. Interesting unit design, the differences between factions are subtle but important enough to result in different strategies
3. Modabillity
4 Nice graphics
5. Subjectively to me: fun gameplay that is slow but deliberate with options for scouting, hiding and planning.
6. My most importan consideration: great skirmish options with fantastic AI!

Cons of the game:

1 Limmited unit varieity, more units in (free) DLC have been promised but so far there are not as many option as for instance SupCom or SC2
2 One win condition: usualy the game is won by capturing more resources and using this income to capture and defend the turinium nodes.
3 Limmited viability of turtling, expansion is key for every phase of the game.

Verdict: 8/10 great game to play, easy to learn but difficult to master. Supcom players need to expect a non-supcom game and be pleasantly suprised by the simmilarities to appreciate the game.

reviewText:
Supreme Commander veterans will be most at home here, but a clone it is not. By borrowing bits and pieces from various other RTS games out there, this game has become it's own beast. Don't go into this expecting it to be exactly like another Supcom/TA.

Ashes of the Singularity is a mixed bag. It is best described as a combination between Supreme Commander and Sins of a Solar Empire. It is an RTS with a streaming economy based around forming groups of units into meta-units (called armies in game), and then fighting over spots on the map that take time to capture like a Relic RTS.

The campaign is honestly pretty meh. The difficulty curve spikes rapidly in places, only to be smooth sailing again for a few stages afterwards. Despite these difficulty spikes, veteran RTS players will probably find themselves blowing through the campaign pretty quickly. I had to surrender twice during the campaign, and both times I finished the stage no problem once I knew what was going to happen.

The story is predictable, rudimentary, and tacked on. The voice acting is pretty terrible, especially for the female. The in battle conversation is just text that is jarring and constantly yanking your view away from what you are trying to do. Not only is the in game text not voice acted (probably a good thing with the poor quality of it anyway), but there aren't even animations or portraits to make it interesting. The in battle dialogue can honestly be skipped, and it wouldn't change the experience much as most of the conversation boils down to, Insert middle-school play complexity of dialogue to justify this battle." The player starts off as a "neophyte" that is brought in to assist the big boys
date: and suddenly about 3/4s of the way through you have apparently made enough of a name for yourself that you are considered "quite powerful." However

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I recommend this game, however only conditionally.

Good things:
It is very playable for an alpha game (one race so far, some features missing, but you can play full games)
The AI is strong with this one, even on lower difficulties it will manage to surprise you, effectively counter attack etc even if it doesn't pull off the win. On the highest difficulties it will slaughter you
Managing your 'economy', territory, upgrades et al is far more important than clicks per minute.
I like the style.

Bad Things:
Most of the bad things result from the fact that it's still in 'pre-beta' and will most likely change. I'll try to remember to update as they do.
No tutorial, no key bind listings, no rules explanation etc. You're just dropped in.
One race/faction so far.
No storyline/campaign
Some in game features missing

Who should buy this game now: Hardcore fans of the genre with a machine powerful enough to run it (My desktop falls into the recommended specs and on ultra experienced some graphical errors, have not and will not be attempting to run it on my laptop). If you were a fan of company of heroes i suggest you give it a whirl.

Who should buy it later: more casual fans of the genre or those who want to wait until it's features have been fully implemented, people who's machine lacks the power.

Who should buy it never: People who hate RTSs, why are you even reading this, why are you here, Get Out!!

N.B. Some play time has been offline, ignore total.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ashes takes a little bit of SupCom (scale, units, streaming economy), a little bit of Sins of a Solar Empire (Dreadnoughts=Capital Ships), and a pinch of Company of Heroes (economy sectors linked on the map to your HQ) to make a pretty cool sci-fi, far future, post-singularity, massive scale game.

It's in Beta2 right now and will launch around the end of March 2016. Beta2 is a big jump up from the previous version. The AI is the best I've played in RTS, there's a working ranked MP ladder with seasons already, and a SP campaign will come at launch. The sound effect work is really satisfyingly well-done, giving character to machines and the graphics are damn purdy. The music is done by 2 composers (from Civ 5 and Battlestar Galactica) and suitably epic and cinematic.

Some gameplay elements that stand out: orbital abilities (global use abilities that run the gamut of offensive and support), grouping units into a meta unit army with its own AI and automatic unit positioning, dreadnought units (kind of super units) that level up and gain abilities, several defensive and support structures to build, a variety of different resources to manage (4 really, including what are essentially victory points" as an alternate win condition).

There's currently 2 factions with a 3rd likely in dlc later. They aren't totally asymmetrical but there are enough differences that they feel different to play and you have some different tactics and unit types available. If you enjoy a slower paced
date: more macro style RTS that takes some inspiration from older games
recommended: you'll easily get your money's worth out of Ashes."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Runs perfectly on my 970gtx / 4690k even with thousands of units on the screen, which is already a major detatchment from how SupCom was at launch!

My positive review comes with a warning: There are a large number of minor problems with the game in its current state.  Such as
- Lack of graphical/icon clarity.  In particular it's very hard to spot whether a resource has an extractor built on it without zooming in, and it's hard to quickly get an idea of the makeup of an army.
- Missing macro features, such as being able to pause factories, assist engineers, have units auto-join armies or follow complex rally paths when built

These things are not fundamental problems, but they are somewhat game-breaking in terms of the game's chance at sucess.  Hopefully Stardock will have learned, finally, that releasing games with these easy-to-fix-but-review-tarnishing issues is not wise, and will make certain that they've been cleared up before official launch.

The game itself has a huge amount of promise, and it's the first of its kind in quite some time.  If it can get these quality of life & polish improvements, it could easily be a hit.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If history repeats itself with what Stardock has achieved in the past with this game, then we will be looking at one of the best RTS games ever made. I have no doubt that this game will go down in the annals of history with such game greats as Home World, Supreme Commander, WiC, SoSE and Wargame(s)

The developers respond to feed back and are very committed/dedicated to the game and they want people to get envolved, they love hearing ideas from the community. Balance is pretty solid, and gets fixed quite quickly if it gets thrown off by an update. There is a pretty solid core group of alpha founders that are very helpful and want to see the game become the best it can be.

1. This game is like chess on steriods.
2. The graphics (specifically models) are better than any game of this scale that I have seen. (at least in 4k!) ;)
3. This is macro not micro, however some abilities, MAY be able to be used in micro, eventually.
4. This game introduces a new unit/command and control concept called the meta unit. THIS IS #$%^ING AWESOME!
5. So many aspects of the game, even the ones that are quite functional are still being worked on, yet the core is pretty solid.
6. On my machine, I have yet to experience game lag. Although, I don't think I have had that many units on screen at one time, maybe couple thousand including AI.
7. I usually play offline, so game hours are a lot more.
8. This game is PRE beta. PRE means before, yeah?, like as in before being a beta? Okay.
9. I have spent2-1/2 times what they are asking for right now, and I have already got MY moneys worth out of it. It has been a blast to watch the game evolve and unfold.

If you like intense strategy games, on a massive scale, where the composition of your force is a form of customization and main tactic to your overall strategy, then you'll like this game, but that doesn't mean you should get it now. But you'll want a powerful system, some patience and some reasonability to what PRE beta means if you do.

System Specs: 4930K Ivy Bridge-E 6 core @4.5Ghz, 16Gig Ram, SSDs, Radeon Fury-X and 4k monitor.

I hope this was helpful.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

just bought it based on stardocks previous rts record and the gameplay/graphics, i am very impressed tho after playing alpha, the game is still missing alot of stuff currently but its just what the market has been missing, ships and robot style units with missiles and lasers, a nice fun mass unit rts, i am a big fan of rts games for 14 years since command and conquer and was a fan of supreme commander, from playing this game, its could morph into what supreme commander 3 should be of should of been (no idea why they stopped making supreme commander games).

it has a decent selection of both units and buildings which all counter different units, defensive buildings are very important but a resource drain on your miltary and static but very useful, the battles are insanely big, resource points are spread evenly around the map similar to how company of heroes does or supreme commander does, so controlling area and expanding is obviously important, you cannot camp in one area for 2 hours and win a game because you will fall behind, you need to both fight and defend from multiple directions as all maps have 2 ways to your base, a good feature they have done is to add neutral defenders to control/resource points, so you cannot roam the map capping everything with engineers, you actually need a miltary presence to expand which is great.

the game seems to have a campaign coming for the story lovers, has single player vs a.i and obviously the juicy multiplayer which apparently is coming with a ranking system, this game is actually using your PC hardware and the latest stuff instead of being dragged down by consoles, its using direct x12 and the graphics are great even in large scale, it ran great on my PC, the gameplay isnt watered down for morons so you have 4 buttons, it feels like a classic rts.

the game does not have the system in place yet to call in arty strikes etc into the game along with other things but the buildings are there so it will be added, the building allows you to collect points from a research style building, this feature will be most likely vital to breaking through heavy enemy defences and causing area of effect damage to your enemies armies along with just being fun, i can just imagine a arty strike hitting a enemy army or a laser cannon from the sky ripping through the enemies base.

the game has been alpha for 5 days at time of writing and i cant wait to see whats added, took me under 5 minutes to buy this game after researching into it. the only way i could imagine this game failing if for some bizarre reason they stopped adding updates to the alpha which would be extremely strange and unlikely, after buying all these alpha and beta games that go no where, with there track record with sins of a solar empire which i loved, i just cant see this failing, i am sure this will turn into a gem, only need a bit of patience :)

reviewText:
If you're the kind of person who is turned off by the break neck speed of Starcraft than this is a game you will probably enjoy. Not to say that this game isn't fast at all, but does not require the micromanagement of other RTS's. There is also a campaign, but acts more like an extended tutorial and lacks any sense of personality. That is not what this game was made for however, and the skirmish mode and multiplayer is where this game shines. Most people seem to compare this game to Supreme Commander, but it actually has more incommon with Sins of a Solar Empire.

Macro over micro, that's one way to describe what you will be doing with this game. Controlling how much resources you're getting and the amount of units that are in you're army still takes a bit of micromanagement, but actual placement of your armies is pretty straight forward. Later, when you geta handle on the nuiances of the units, you get a feel for when you should attack, defend, and where to place defences and use powers. One of the weaknesses of the win conditions however is that there is a resource you get and if someone gets enough of it then they win the match. This can be a bumber and forces a more aggressive strategy; and also just makes the game feel like you weren't able to experience the full joy of creating just enormous armies of units to crush your enemies with. Thankfully this can be turned off or turned up to an enormous amount, so that you have to take out your oppenents' bases to end the match in glorious destruction.

If you have ever played Sins, then you can see a sort of similarity in the flow of combat. You and your opponents struggle for control of certain nodes that have resources connected to them, much like the planets in Sins but a bit faster. There only two types of resources to make units, but this keeps things simple and only the more advanced units use the rarer one. Which brings me to the dreadnoughts, much like in Sins, these behemoths can level up and gain more abilities, health, and fire power. As of right now there are only three of them, but with afore mentioned abilities you can create armies to specialize in different forms of warfar, such as long range bombardment, close range support, and aggressive damage.

There's also only two different factions, but they are well balanced and feel very solid with enough differences to feel alien to the other. One faction, the humans (who have created the singularity and uploaded themselves into computers) behave like most stereotypical human factions and should feel very familiar to veterans of the genre and new players should find them easy to use, the Substrate however behave differently. Many of their units use Power to fire their weapons and if they run out, they can't fire. This balanced out with humans because the Substrate's weapons are quite powerful and always hit, with the exception of the artillary units and a few others. Having only two different factions may sound like a draw back, but it actually feels just right for this game and I wouldn't be surprised if they did announce they were going to make another faction but does not bring the game down at this time.

Overall this is a game for capital S, Strategy gamers. Managing your supply lines of units and locations of your armies is paramount. This is a very solid entry to the strategy genre and takes after greats such as Supreme Commander and Sins. This is also a good game for newcomers to the genre, with simplier, yet nuanced strategies that demand much from the player in order for them to become good, but are also simple enough for them to understand.

reviewText:
Good game, especially for single player (campaign's alright, skirmish is excellent, and AI is very good, without cheating). I have played next to no multiplayer, but I can attest that there were always people online whenever I checked.

This game is a bit of a spiritual successor to Total Annihilation (NOT Supreme Commander, lest you get confused), and borrows the Company of Heroes resource mechanic and emphasis on offense (you must capture nodes and have them all be connected to collect resources). These are the two games Ashes is most like, again, it is not similar to Supreme Commander in any way besides large (uncapped!) unit counts.

Right now, the primary means of winning is Boom and Rush, though the devs have indicated improved turtling mechanics coming up (The developers of this game are extremely active, with updates adding features, units, maps, tweaks, etc. released very nearly every week). That said, as it is now (and even after more turtling options), if you aren't constantly pushing, you will not win. There is no time to sit back, and fortifications exist primarily to lock down a specific forward operating base or delay an enemy advance.

If all that sounds like your cup of tea, you'll love Ashes! If you're a fan of strategy in general, you will at least enjoy it. If the fun of strategy for you is to turtle up, build an economy behind your impenetrable walls, and then advance on the enemy, this game will not be for you.

I tend to lean closer to Turtle/Boom (and hate rushing), so while I can recommend this game regardless of your playstyle, as it is well crafted and enjoyable, I would caution players that like pure Turtle best to pick it up on a sale.

reviewText:
Positive:

- great if you want to play large scale battles with many units on a big map and don't care for anything else
- music, audio effects

Negative:

- the single player campaign is a joke: no voiceover for ingame messages/interactions between the characters, no subtitle under videos, short and only 11 missions, the story is above average.
- graphics:  while some effects are well developed some parts of the game looks horrible (terrain, ground textures, random graphical glitches)
- maps are boring, the level design should improve
- gameplay related bugs, glitches even after several months of beta testing
- ridiculous things for a PC exclusive title like you have to restart the game every time you change a video setting (even the most basic ones like resolution/fullscreen or windowed mode).
- badly optimized: while DX12 will allow slower CPU's to catch up, it's ridiculous you need the latest flagship graphics cards for 1080p@60 experience - it does not look THAT good.

The whole game feels like it's still in early access - An unfinished, unpolished early CONCEPT of a game.

Big (boring) maps and thousands of units are not necessairly the key to the success...

Improve the gameplay experience: better story, better single player campaign, better level design. It does not have to be huge - sometimes less is more...
These are my suggestions for the next game (if there will be any) because the technology itself looks promising.

voteText: 32 of 39 people (82%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
This game is simply fantastic.
The games biggest standout is that the units micro for you. ++++
Games like starcraft or Men of War Assault Squad that require you to Micro (click on individual units and issue orders to each unit) which require a lot of work, this game does it for you.

Build some units and you already have an army on the field? Click and drag around one army and just right click on the other army to form them up no shift click or alt-click to do anything. They form up, and you just have to press Control + 1. Medics stay in the back and heal units, without you ordering them to.
2. Once you get the ability to build the next set of units called frigates you can simply click on the UI and request units to rally on them, no more going back to factories and building units and then setting rally points.

This game really sets the focus on gameplay.
You can even do what I said for #2 with massive units called Dreadnoughts. Huge floating ships that after they kill enough units. They can upgrade their abilities to better suit your needs.

I would say Stardock really did a good job on this game.  Take my advice TRY IT OUT!

Best of all, the game isn't even done yet!!
voteText: 26 of 29 people (90%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Parallels are drawn between this game and other games such as planetary anihilation and supreme commander. Its a fair comparison. While theres enough micromanagement to make this game immersive, Ashes is mostly about grand strategy and thinking moves/minutes ahead of your opponent. Rush tactics, flanking, unit counters and global abilities.

Pros
-AI lives up to the hype, its pretty smart (not human level, dont worry)
-Grand strategy, brain ache.
-Large scale, largest games do get to a couple of thousand (not counting drones)
-Big plans for the future, they want to add 3rd faction etc... Stardock usually look after a game once released.

Cons
-Uninteresting terrain.
-Lack of story to Campaign, 11 missions too short,  missions feel a little like a tutorial until the last couple.

Overall, i'm going to get plenty of hours from this, but i'll all be on mulitplayer, vs AI or player. Finally a game that puts the 'S' back in RTS.

reviewText:
UPDATE
Over a month into the game and Stardock has stayed true to their promises on balance, addition of units, and maps. What I was not expecting was it to come so soon, and with the addition of new scenarios. Additionally, they have announced voiceovers to the campaign and continue to address almost every issue that both the playerbase and critical reviewers have had.

Reasons to buy this game:
-Stardock's commitment to its players
-Great strategic gameplay
-Two unique factions with their own strengths/weaknesses (a third is in the making)
-Large and small maps that play very differently
-Viable Rush-Boom-Turtle
-Looks amazing
-Growing Game modes

Reasons to NOT buy the game:
-If you can only get it for full price (at least I dont like to pay)
-If your system cannot handle the game (it is very hardware intensive)
-If you want to micro manage units (there are many things happening at once)
-Fleshing out is still needed (although in only a month they have done a lot)


PREVIOUS REVIEW

My outlook on this game based on the beta is very good. The development team has done one of the best jobs I have ever seen replying and responding to player feedback, criticism, and suggestions on how the game should play. Stardock has been known to support game changes/patches well into the lifespan of their games and I do not see any reason to believe that Ashes of The Singularity will be any different.

Game-play has come a long way since Pre-Beta when I first purchased the game and I can only see it improving from here. Many of the thumbs down reviews came early on and in Beta when the stability of the game was still an issue. The community is also a very strong. As far as I can tell it is not toxic and although there are disagreements, it is rare to see bad reactions in discussions and forums.

If you enjoy the RTS genre then Ashes of The Singularity is a perfect game to try out. It takes inspiration from several previous games, but has its own flavor. It is easy to learn, yet hard to master and the replay-ability seems to be endless even in its current state. The dev team has laid out a specific road map going further so I can only see it getting better. The engine is brand new and therefore this game will be perfect with mods and the only thing holding it back is this generation's hardware.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now, this is my first review despite being on steam for years now and i thought this would be a good place to start, now normally you would need to plays hours of a game to get a good sense of what it is, how it does, etc. but ive only played 39 minutes of the game, and i want to give my first impressions on the game, i will keep this updated as i play more, now lets get the obvious negatives about the game, and keep in mind it is early access so you should expect it, so here we go.

Obvious visual bugs:

- so first of are the visual bugs, when units take damage there textures do freak out a little, nothing really noitcable unless your zoomed right in, but this will be something the devs are bount to fix.
- textures, shaders, lighting can get really flippy if you start panning the angle of the camera to far from its default view, low res/ wierd textures and pop-ins, kinda like what you have with supreme commander, those who try get the cinematic shots will know what im on about.

Performance:

- now i have the reccomened specs, with the accpetion of ram, on 8GBs, but man this game can get laggy. Ive only play 1v1 but whne it get intense the frame starts to drop, again its early access and i expected this from the get go, zomming out or at diffrent angles while small battles are happening also effect performance, so for me this is a must fix, or atleast omptimze the game as much as humanly possible.

factions:

- now either i havent play enough or there just isnt enough factions, now i hope the devs are going for the planetary annliation effect wheres theres only one faction, again very early review so i maybe complete wrong, im sure someone will correct me on this if i am wrong.

Other bugs/ issues:

- some wierd bugs with advanced factory where a placehold titan, if im calling them right seems to overlay everything when your building one, bit wierd.

Now thats over and done with, so what about the games, graphics, art style, etc. Well thats where this game shines, let me exsplain:

Those who have played supreme commander will feel at home with the controls, the kind of akward camera which takes a little time to get used to, massive battles which i have yet to fully experience, wacky units, etc. the art style is simliar to planetary annilation, but less cartony which is a great choice.

Graphicly with all bugs put to side the game does look good, textures could use with a little coat of paint but thats just me, been playing battlefront beta and ive beet spoilt with graphics, but its good for a mordern day rts and a ealy access game. Exsploins, unit deaths and battle effects as i call them are like a mordern day supreme commander, missle volleys are amazing, plama effects are very good, cannons firing look and feel good, you can see what i mean in videos onn youtube or on the store page.

Gameplay it very fun, and again its feel like superme commander mixed with planetary annilation, it is very solid and enjoyable to witness.

Balance is somewhat of an issue depending how you look at it, once you start building more powerful units, your lighter earlier units are pointless, just like supreme commander and PA, this can be either a good or bad thing depending on what your play style is.

Overall once this game is complete, and has a few extra factions, spit and polish to the graphics and has beenbug stompt, i can truthly say that this would be a supreme commander 3, it just feels good to play, looks goods and takes element of classic rts games and matches them so the work well together. i will be updating this as i play more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just bought this game on sale for the half price weekend...awesome deal. Glad i waited till the other faction was out.

Similar to supcom...push space and you can see a quick overview of the sections you need to capture. Still in beta so no tutorial or campaign but play it on beginner ai in skirmish mode and you will figure it out.

Pretty cool game so far, even though its just a beta. I like the upgrade system and you are constantly trying to balance spending your metal/radioactives and something called quanta (which you need for global upgrades). its cool bc radioactive is your most vital resource as you need it to build the bigger ships, resource improvement upgrades and to build quanta generators...so you have to balance your current military and size with bigger ships vs bigger dmg/health/resource or fleet capacity upgrades. more closely related to supcom forged alliance than supcom 2 (which trust me is a GOOD thing).

This game is well done, and this thing looks beautiful even on my windows 7 comp (direct x 12 gets you a few more bells and whistles but who cares..it looks beautiful and i refuse to upgrade to windows 10 until microsoft gives up on forcing you to accepa ALL updates. for a bit of improvement graphically to me its not worth it but i digress.

Anyways, great game. if you like supcom forged alliance but want somethign with newer graphics, better optimization (That can actually use all 4 cores and your beefy GPU (nvidia 980 TI for me lol) then you won't be dissapointed.

played this for only a few matches but lots of fun and I am sure once the campaign comes out and they tweak a few things this going to take the rightful place of where supcom 3 should have been.


Buy it, especially now that its on for half price, you won't regret it :)

reviewText:
This game has a strange, almost hypnotic appeal for me.  I'm fairly sure it has to do with how relieving it feels to send an army to a place and know that you wont have to worry about a group of tanks shooting railguns haplessly into the ground, rather than the enemy.  Sounds ridiculous, but that is absolutely something that will happen in say, Deserts of Kharak (which is a fine game despite issues like that).

It is by no means perfect: it needs more content and the content that is there could use more fleshing out.
Right now the game is generally nice on the eyes and oddly hypnotic and serene for an RTS.

I feel like an expansion could turn this from a pretty good game into an excellent game, but only time will tell.

reviewText:
Great RTS game with a huge potential to grow even larger and better + Technology behind the game is great - huge battles that work as it should and look good

reviewText:
Pros-

* Great graphics
* Great looking ships
* Buildings looks cool
* Love the concept of the areas to capture to show map control
* Massive warfare

Cons-

* Poor unit variety
* Campaign has a difficulty spike that has resulted in a lot of irritation, it severely limits your income and expects you to fight hordes of enemies that you can't even produce enough metal to fight against.
* You need a really good computer to run this. I have a GTX 970, and i still only get 30fps when there are a lot of units on screen, if you don't have a good computer, do not buy the game.
* The campaign is not really a campaign, it's text driven with cutscenes inbetween missions with no real story on the origins of the species etc.
* The buildings when you set them down have to be far apart or they won't build. If you set a build qeue and accidently put one too close to another with your engineer, it will shut the entire operation down.

The game has evolved since the alpha, but the game overall is a fun game. The pros of being a massive warfare and a good looking game make this a must buy, but on sale not at full price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It has prommise, but so far there just isn't anything that makes it any more than a Supreme Commander clone. The units are all very similar and there isn't much tactical decision making. Expand like crazy early on, build up a giant death ball and swarm. It's a game that rewards unfettered agression as the unit cap is immense (with upgrades) and defensive structures are innefective against swarms of units (not to mention really expensive). The game despirately needs large scale AoE weapons like nukes or shield generators to make defense more effective.

It's not a bad game and I certainly haven't mastered it, but the RTS elements are shallow and unrewarding.

reviewText:
Post Launch Review:

So my early access review was quite negative. I had hoped that after launch and some patches that the game would miraculously shape up. Sadly that is not the case. The game still looks bad, sounds bad, and plays bad.

Interface - Dreadful. While everything is in the correct place, its tiny (you can make it smaller but not larger?), and full of wasted space for useless artwork. All feels like placeholder art and not final cut.

Sounds - Dreadful (this is a theme here). Again this feels very much like a bunch of random cheap placeholders and not something that had any serious effort put into it. I wouldnt mind it so much if there was some ambient chatter going on, some auditory feedback from your troops, but instead all your hear is endless pew pew pew and whatever the hell that BIORG sound your medics make when they leave the factory. Ugh.

Gameplay - Almost Dreadful. You make armies, which are essentially roaming warbands of tiny things on your screen that look meaningless until you start spitting out dreadnoughts. You move your blobs from one target to another, hoping you have more guns than they do or luckily a better combination of units to counter theirs. The strategic layer of capturing nodes seems wonderful at first, but then it becomes such a massive chore due to the fact that you must babysit your chain very carefully or a sneaky enemy will break through your lines/frontier and cut the chain. So you turtle, keeping it all tightly buttoned up, leaving no holes. Fun at first, and then it gets extremely annoying.

A lot of problems would go away if the game didnt require such a fantastic amount of micro management. Without any auditory feedback as to whats happening you are constantly checking all over the map for red things on your radar, your units being attacked (they dont tell you they are), enemy units bombing your resources etc. You simply cannot just enjoy a battle as a lack of focus elsewhere can be crippling.

Overall - It could be good, but it would require serious overhauling of how the game looks and functions. The game is highly reminiscent of stardocks old offering, Elemental, whereby the first game was incredibly weak, but two followup revisions (Fallen Enchantress) eventually fleshed out the look and the formula. This is what this game needs, a makeover, or two.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Original Early Access Review:

Beta 2 early impressions: My initial review is that this game is still very rough and incomplete. Total Annihilation a decade+ ago looked better. Why? Because it was much more clear what I was looking at. Here while everything has far more detail when zoomed in, zoomed out it all looks like nonsense and you need to play zoomed out to see the battlefield. As is this game does not clearly present to you what units you have, what units youre lacking (due to being destroyed and thus knowing what to rebuild), and what is happening far away from your attention. Buildings getting attacked? Hope you noticed the color change on the minimap as thats the only thing conveying useful information at this time.

The other big killer of fun and happiness are orbital weapons. Got an army? Want to atttack the enemy? Poof, your army is gone. Orbital weapon took it out. You cant move out of the blast range fast enough. Only way to avoid it is to turtle extremely slowly building anti-orbital buildings along your path. And if it wasnt for the orbital weapons, siege dreadnoughts that wipe out anything that isnt a dreadnought essentially guarantees that in the endgame you will build just two things: aircraft to harrass the enemy and dreadnoughts. Anything smaller need not apply as it gets wiped out instantly.

The game however is promising and very much in the category of diamond in the rough"."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As the game is now, you wouldnt be able to tell it was in early access by a glance at the video, and one or two games. Ill start off with the pro's and con's now.

Pro's:
Absolutly fantastic graphics
Good unit composition/variety/blance
Good economy system
Research/upgrade system seems solid
Has the makings of a great RTS

Con's
Units move painfully slow (understandable if they want a slow paced game/its early access and they dont want fast moving units to ♥♥♥♥ up the game)
Unit AI (that is how units move/execute when you give them an order) is lacking greatly
Builder AI, When i give the workers an order (shift click/move/build) I expect each worker to start on a building or all of them help the first. This doesnt happen, essentially wasting time and money.
Maps seem to be really made to break up unit movement. (Alot of mountainous terrain)

Ideas for the game
Allow move speed to be one of the upgrades available
Scrap the worker system and allow buildings to be built from the capturable points. (if you want to have a factory build faster, make the factory upgradeable/scaleable.)

This seems to be the game i will look forward to replace the hole in my heart that Total Annihilation left, due to its being outdated and without a competent successor. (Im ♥♥♥♥ing looking at you Suckcom.)

reviewText:
Good game. I like RTS games with stream economy. Especially comes alive for me in MP. But with a campaign, scenarios and good AI to play on plenty of available skirmish maps there is a fair amount to do for SP lovers too (and I play them too). Especially as you can create your own maps and scenarios; you can find a guide on how to do it here: http://www.moddb.com/games/ashes-of-the-singularity

For those curious about performance I run the game on a i7 4790k with a 970 FTW and 32GB of RAM (overkill for me but someone else uses the computer for video editing). I run the game @ 1920x1200 (16:10 ftw :)) on Extreme settings with AA turned up to 8x from the default 4x. A game will start with about 60+ FPS but in big battles etc. will go into the 40s, which for me on an RTS is fine. And it looks gooood :) (and perhaps more importantly no sim slow down!). A friend is able to run it on High settings with a 7970/280x.

Hmm, not a big believer in reviews in general as you don't know me and you have no idea if my likes align with yours. If you want to know specifics I can edit this and go into it.
For what it's worth though the game is a lot of fun for me, though not perfect. Most of the areas I want the game to improve on all seem to be in the pipeline though. When we get things like navy, 12 player map support, another faction and smaller things like wreckage and reclaiming then I think this will go from being a very decent fun RTS to a genuinely great RTS to be played for many years to come.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Why did I buy it?

I cut my teeth on Supreme Commander, and I was excited for this game becuase I looked like it captured a lot of the key elements from SupCom; crazy scale, ♥♥♥ loads of units, real time resources (and two primary resources at that), sci-fi styles,  and exceptional use of new technology. I was excited to see these features presented from a 2016 perspective (I skipped Planetary Annihilation because it was kind of expensive, and because the unit scale on the planets threw me off).

First Impression

I was pretty lost. Normally I'd go right for the campaign, and then if that was hard I'd find a tutorial. Both of these things were missing from the Early Access, which I have 0 beef with. Instead you get an online walkthrough, which worked well enough for my purposes. On the second attempt, I ran the benchmark first (as instructed, and was pleasantly surprised to see my framrate stayed aboce 30 for even the most intense scenes). Also, the music and graphics for the loading screen are very pleasant (though I doubt you started reading this review to hear that), they both serve to remind that this is a very current game with a lot of potential.

First Battle

(First Battle Where I Understood What To Do *) Most of the standard RTS tropes are in there and implemented well. I had no issue with unit control, althouth this is where I have my first complaint. Maybe it's because I haven't played enough, or maybe it's because I wasn't wearing my glasses, but I found the units hard to tell apart, and so are the structures. With the graphics being as powerful as they are, I'd like to think units and structures could be a little more distinct (to me they're all sci-fi blobs), but honestly this doesn't really take away from the experience. Idle engineers are on F1, and when you're building a huge army to act as one meta-unit, you stop giving a ♥♥♥♥ about it's actual unit composition so long as there's a little of everything. Harking back to SupCom, I liked how some units walked on 2, 4, 6, or 8 legs, some hovered, some flew, some floated (?), and some had tracks. Here, they fly or hover. This doesn't even qualify as a complaint, it's merely a gripe from a die hard.

The battle basically resulted in me spawning a few small armies, a few big armies, and then overrunning them with a hord. Two big compliments here. I love love love the AI and how it controls armies. I feel a little removed, but it's cool to see your subordinates take up the fight. Another nice touch was the resource system, and how it lends itself to map exploration and territory control. Essentially, nodes in an almost gridlike pattern are scattered across the map. Controlling nodes grants resources, and exploring the grid eventually leads to pronounced frontlines as teams fight over strategic nodes.

How would I Improve it / Should you buy it?

(What would I add from SupCom / Should You Buy It? *) Let me say that I picked it up 50% off, and I probably wouldn't buy an early access game in any situation without that stipulation. That said, it's already a lot of fun, and I look forward to seeing this game evolve. I have very high hopes for it, and I expect it to do reasonably well as it's a nice new take on a genre that could use some invigorating. NOW, here's a couple things I'd like see. Dreadnoughts are your Big MFs; take a lot of resources, does a lot of damage, has a lot of hit points, etc. I know they do different things (there's three to choose from), but I don't know the difference and tbh I don't care. None of them were -captivating-. This would be the only catergory where I could say I expected bigger things from this game. I was gonna go off about how I want more and bigger dreadnoughts, more frigates, more units, maybe superdreadnoughts, etc, but I think I can summarize it this way.
The units don't excite me. This could be a beta issue, maybe there's more on the way, but right now they all just seem like unimaginitive sci-fi RTS stereotypes, and the Big MFs aren't big enough. They all just shoot different coloured lasers or rockets.

TL;DR

This is a really great game, especially considering it's stil in beta, but I'd like it more if it were more like Supreme Commander.

reviewText:
I bought this game for two particular reasons:
Its concept as a reduced-micro, large scale RTS, with meta-units designed to reduce the APM burden.
Multicore design and next-gen DX for future proofing.Ashes delivers on those two premises most of the time. Given that it is a game that is released with the near-certainty of extended ongoing support, this is... satisfactory.
The current meta-unit (armies) implementation in v1.1 does most of the job, although it is missing nuances such as stances (aggressive/skirmishing/etc. akin to Homeworld-series and Dark Reign setups). There are many improvements in the details, making armies one good way to remove the need to set specific unit behvaiours as they are produced.
Armies eliminate hair-splitting nuisances like coordinating air units with ground armies when you are lazy, and reinforcements (equivalent to Sins fleets).
The support units within the army will automatically focus on what they do best, rather than e.g. rushing into battle while abilities are on cooldown (ala Hoshikos & several other support cruisers in Sins Rebellion with autoattack left on.)
Snipers will stay ranged, and at times kite (similar to AI-War autokite ranges)
Units like melee frigates will generally sit and guard ranged units in the same army rather than swarm in. This last one is contentional, and is one of the areas where army stances will help. Some players have complained about it validly, because zerg-rushing is sometimes the best choice. Given the game meta, it is not as common to see siege situations where you actually want to wait for artillery to do its job. There are things that are desired but missing, like attaching engineers with automated instructions to upgrade or fortify captured regions - one of the tasks that is still very click-heavy (SupCom extractor mechanics... -_-). They auto-form armies, which is usually good. I would often wish to split an army into two (AI War), detach forward scouts or filter-select them (AI War again), and skirmishing/i.e. attempt to draw enemies into concaves (Starcraft micro). These are the sort of things you shouldn't need to micro as the overall commander (rather than commander of that army) ..I suppose those kind of improvement  will come in time and with the relevant maps.

= = =
The other-bit about multicore usage is particularly relevant for AI. While performance is generally GPU-bound until you obtain a beastly pair of GPUs, adding 5 AIs in a match will pretty much guarantee big slowdowns on a standard desktop PC. In v1.1, the game doesn't particularly care about the CPU's max performance (nor do most programs for that matter): you add the AI, and the AI will spawn all the threads that it needs down to every last turret on a cruiser.

So it's not meant to be a game for massive AI skirmishes until the average desktop has 16+ cores. It's something that I'd be curious to test in a supercluster setting... >_>

The hardware will eventually catch up.
= = =
In the mean time, I think it is worth an investment to tell the developers and the overall gaming community that the RTS-genre can be other things than micro-fests (which should be called istead real-time tactics). The devs are continuing to add maps and units (niche-filling units), and are on-track to release DLCs that won't need you to keep buying to stay abreast of the MP community (Wargame series...). That is, players without DLC content will be able to play with players that do.

reviewText:
This is a great game.    At first glance, it looks like it's a Supreme Commander or Planetary Annihilation type of game.   It's not, so don't go into this expecting that.   Ashes is definitely it's own game and that imo is better for the genre.   To me, Ashes is a hybrid between SupCom and traditional base builders like Starcraft or Grey Goo.    Although you can mass huge armies, the base building and resources are far more reserved than SupCom.    You won't be spamming turrets, and base defenses while building massive armies.

Resources force you to expand around the map, plus they have a domination type game mode mechanic where you have to capture certain generator points on the map.   Whoever can hold most of the points until they go critical mass wins.   So it's a dual win condition...the generator points or just wipe out the enemy.

The units themselelves are outstanding and impressive.   It's like having a space or naval fleet on the ground.   You have frigates, larger cruisers, then the massive dreadnaughts.   In addition, you have orbital abilities that can be researched and used as well as a unit upgrade system.   Both factions are very unique and not just mirror's of each other.    A huge upgrade for the game is the fact the units micro themselves.   So you don't have to worry about them if you need to concentrate on another part of the map.

The campaign is very good and challenging.   It took me longer than the SupCom 2 campaign.   Overall this is a must buy imo for any RTS fan.   And best of all, the developers are continuing to update and add to the game.

reviewText:
Current State 4/2/16
Rating 6.5/10

I would not recommend this game if you want a good single player/campaign experience.  If you want to play Multiplayer or Skirmish, then you should be fine.

I just tried the first mission and I was stuck on a cut scene of a bomber run.  The bombers came in and my screen was locked in place.  Unable to move, go back, just stuck in place.

I feel like there was a lot of good effort done for the skirmish and multiplayer. However, it came at the cost of the single player.  In addition, there are no characters, no personalities, and virtually no story line.  And that was something I was really looking forward to.

I remember playing C&C with story lines about Kane or Supreme Commander and the UEF.  Instead I get a text box with names that I can barely read.  I feel like I am just sitting here reading someone else’s text messages lol.

The intro to the first mission was really interesting and the actual game mechanics are solid so far.  I would just recommend either they fix the story line or use the revenue to make a good story line for the next game.  If they do decide to add/change the story line, at the very least just add a voice over.  That is all I really need.  Supreme Commander had a really good voice over and cut scenes.  Mix that with the fluid game mechanics and you will be good.

reviewText:
Short disclaimer: I really tend to focus on the gameplay aspect of things. I just don't care a lot about fancy graphics or what not.

I go this game because they made single player AI one of their main sellings points. And I usually don't do online multiplayer, for RTS games anyways. So I went into this with the expectation of playing skirmishes mainly. That said I'm currently playing mostly multiplayer. So I guess singleplayer really must suck?
Quite the opposite. The AI really is comparably good. From what I know, the vast majority of players are at a level where the AI doesn't need any advantages whatsoever to challenge them. They even added another difficulty level for people to get used to the playing at 100%. But of course there are also the higher difficulties and all but the hardest one have been beaten by players in a 1 vs 1 setting.
And then there's multiplayer. What surprised me the most was that skill versus the AI really does translate to skill versus players. Of course there are differences and everything, but if you're good at beating the AI you're probably also good at beating people. And that's not as obvious as it might sound, seeing how in many RTS I've played the high difficulty singleplayer experience was just so different from actual multiplayer that you could be the king of singleplayer and still suck versus people. And that's a good thing because it makes it a lot easier to start playing multiplayer casually without getting stomped all the time.

Now, not everything is flowers and rose petals.
The campaign isn't really story driven. Sure, there is a story, but it didn't make me care about things. A lot of people seemed to find some missions really challenging, but it's all very beatable. That said the devs have announced to rework the campaign, make the difficulty adjustable and work on the story. Also add more content.
For skirmish there's really not a lot to complain about I feel.
As for multiplayer... I obviously like it. The queue times are okay, it just sometimes happens that there aren't enough high ranked players in the queue. So sometimes high ranked players get matched against low ranked players if the system couldn't find a more suitable opponent. It has been getting a lot better, though, as the number of players increased. It is my impression, however, that while there are not a lot of mid tier players". At least I barely get matched with any.

As a finishing note I just wanted to state that the devs are very active on the steam forums
date: have constantly adapted and improved their game (post release) until now. And I fully expect them to keep doing what they're doing. They announced new units
hoursPlayed: a polished campaign and a lot more things. And they delived what they promised in the past."

reviewText:
Awesome RTS in the same vein as Supreme Commander. It needs work, dont get me wrong it is in no way perfect but the developers are active on the forums and will listen to any and all feedback.

Pros
-Massive scale, tons of units/buildings on screen.
-Above average AI that will keep you interested in Skirmish/SP if your not an MP RTS fan.
-Not super micro intensive, much more macro oriented. Others would argue this, but its my opinion.
-Formation system that allows easy control for when your army grows to ridiculous sizes.
-Runs on an engine designed with new and upcoming hardware in mind.

Improvements needed
-More unit choices that add strategic options. Especially aircraft. Maybe even an orbital layer of gameplay, albeit it would probably end up a little redundant.
-Orbital abilites arent fun to use/engaging. C&C3 is IMO a good example of support powers done right.
-Controls and unit movement are wonky at times.
-Sound ques for units under attack or map indications for battles taking place/enemy units detected, etc.
-Walker or tread units pretty please :)

Cons
-Needs a mid/high end computer to run well.
-Depending on the map being played, strategy can be limited.
-Some imbalance, but thats always a problem for RTS games.
*My biggest peeve with the game is that it doesnt really shine bright in any one way, its not the first to be massive, graphic and sound design choices are samey/generic, OST doesnt stand out. I mean its all of good quality but just lacks that Oomph in so many areas.


All in all I definitely recommend it if your looking for a change from SupCom or just need a new RTS game that offers up massive scale with its own style of gameplay.

reviewText:
Early access and pre-release games dont always hit the mark right away. This one misses in couple of fashions but more than makes up for it in others. If you combine the positives and the evidence of continued developement and communication I believe this game deserves more that a chance.

Pros

-DX12 :
Any new technology will have its issues. For example most overlays dont work for the DX12 version and the developers disabled them by default but allowed the user to change that in the game settings. Even though at the moment this is a shortcoming this feature is an important step in improving all RTS games.

-Reward and Punishment
The slow pace of this strategy game allows for more calculated choices as a player. Personaly I enjoy this aspect as opposed to the lightnight fast actions of Starcraft 2. A choice by the player may be the wrong one, and an out of place army does not move quickly. Conversly, if you catch an oponent overextending you can create an opening in their defenses.

-Active development
The developers of this game are doing a good job of supporting and communicating about their game to the players. If they conintue this trend they should have one of the best RTS games in the industry.


Cons

-Simple Story Mode
Thats all there is to it. It is just a set of missions to be played in order that is supported by a light narative.

-Imbalance and bugs
There are several bugs and ballance issues that are present at this time, all of which are acknowleged by the developers.

All in all, if you love slow strategic RTS games this is the one for you so long as you have the patience for the early access proccess.

reviewText:
As an individual who generally loves RTS games, but is also generally terrible at them (take that as you will), I would truly recommend this game.

I'll keep the review short and simple:

Pros:
-The game handles phenomenally well, even with hundreds of units on the screen my setup doesn't flinch (I run an i5 and an AMD Radeon R9 285 with 8gb of ram), which really testifies to the optimization

-Controlling the units is easy, and with the army system, the units will organize themselves into a logical formation

-Maps are competetive, though slightly lacking (more on that later)

-Supreme Commander style economy, which I feel lends itself to this 4x style of RTS

-AI is actually challenging and even the normal AI can put up a decent resistance

-Tremendously active dev's as per usual for stardock

Cons:
- As mentioned, the maps are a little bland. As of now, the maps don't have distinct differences in height except for mountain ranges which are simply unpassable.

-Unit variety is somewhat limited, with only 2 factions in the game, each of them has 3-4 viable frigates, 3-4 cruisers, 3 aircraft, and 3 dreadnoughts. While this sounds like a fair amount of units, I've won a number of games by simply making one of each on repeat and throwing my units at my opponent, but perhaps this changes at the upper tiers of ranked (I am only rank 6)

-Only 2 factions at launch. This wouldn't be so much of a problem if the factions weren't so similar. Each faction has essentially the same number of units that fulfill essentially the same roles, with some variations (e.g. the PHC only has AA on cruisers, while the Substrate has AA frigates)

-Still a little buggy, but I expected as much (what game isn't these days?)


Overall a great RTS experience that I will be playing for quite a while.

reviewText:
Big battles: check. Base building: check. Multiplayer, both ranked and co-op: check. Pretty good non-cheating AI: check.

This game is not the whole package. It's a solid foundation from a game development company that actively supports its games for years. There is a lot of room for improvement, and the dedicated development staff to make it happen. Take modding, for example. It is possible to tweak many numbers in the game. It is possible to create maps and custom scenarios. It is not, however, possible to share mods and maps on Steamworks or play the mods in multiplayer...YET! The modding capability is currently minimal, but shows promise of being rich. Yeah the UI could (and will) see some improvements, the units look and move very similarly, the tech tree is a little boring, and there's not much life and character in the maps and campaign...YET! The developers have a history of listening to, interacting with, and soliciting ideas from the community. Some of my own feedback offered during the alpha stage was pulled into the game.

Despite the foundational state of the game, it's actually fun anyway. A focus on macro, not so much micro, means you are conquering the map at a higher more strategic level. The AI actually controls behavior of your units within armies in a fairly intelligent way, so you don't have to micro them. Beneath the initial facade of more units = win" is a strategic depth involving army compositions. This means a skilled player can adapt the makeup of his armies to fight using devastating and cost-efficient counter-armies. Combined with strategies for map control

reviewText: Ashes is a unique game in both its concept, and in its execution. Of course it does borrrow elements from other games (there really isn't anything that is 100% new) but the way that it takes these known quantities and puts them together is certainly unique. What I like best is the slow, methodical gameplay matched with the huge scale of the game. At first I thought that the game was just to slow, but once you get on a four player map the speed is perfect. Much faster and it would become unmaneagable. The speed also forces you to think ahead since the time between ordering an army to an area and said army reaching this area is to long to reward fast reactions to enemy movements. You already need a plan to counter your opponents strategy and the units in place to do that. The game is still fluid, but it is certainly methodical which I like. Also, the AI is tough. I gaurantee that you will find a difficulty setting that will crush you. Army building is also fascinating. The mix of units in a given army will determine what it can best do and these units actually act together as a cohesive whole. For those of you who played Battle for Middle Earth II and its expansion, this means no more calvary rushing into pikemen because you left them on their own for a whole 2 seconds. Overall I would highly recommend this game to anyone who likes RTS. It is challenging and rewarding. I can hardly wait to see how this game evolves through expansion and updates.\n\nP. S. For those of you with a R9 380 the max non-custom setting you can run at is Standard" at 35 FPS. What you need to do is turn the setting to "Extreme" and then disable MSAA and turn the terrain shading to low and the textures to mid. This will give you about 45 FPS and the graphical quality will be much better. I am running a Sapphire R9 380 and an i5 6600k."

reviewText:
Alright, early review 2 hours in.

It's fun. Might be the best RTS I've played since Supreme Commander.
TL;DR - if you're into the unit special abilities and micro-management (think C&C RA 3) then this is not for you. If you're into the larger-scale conflicts, moving entire armies around for key resource control (think Supreme Commander 1) then this is worth a shot.


Very focused on the macro level - the Army system (where armies of units grouped together are controlled as one) messes up occasionally (sent my medics in on the front lines, got torn to shreds by defences) but generally coordinates my forces about as effectively as I would end up doing myself. But it's utility is not in it's micromanagement of unit positions. You can see all the units in the group and ORDER REINFORCEMENTS. They will be added to your factory build queues, and will find their own way over to the army and fall in rank when complete. I think this might be my favourite RTS mechanic of all time. Seriously Devs, you're the best <3.

Unit diversity is OK. Nothing quite as bonkers as SupCom, but with simplicity comes ability to focus on the macro again. Don't have to worry about building 30xT1 interceptors to hold off the enemy 5xT3 bombers. Just think more fighters" and that's it.
But equally I like bonkers. I like spending 2 hours building an experimental artillery piece capable of wiping out entire planets. Here it's just Rocket Defence

reviewText:
A must buy for strategy gamers.

First off, this is Stardock, so release is, unfortunately for them, not really an end result.  This isn't to say the release is bad, in the case of Ashes it's already a fantastic game, it's just going to grow a great deal over time.  It gets them a lot of undeserved grief as people play a game that will continue to evolve and expand, potentially for several years or longer, decide it wasn't quite good enough to have a long shelf life, and write it off without ever finding out just how long the company actually supports their products and how fantastic they end up being.

This game is NOT Supreme Commander.  There are no shield bubbles, there is no strategic artillery, this isn't even an open map game design.  It's all about taking and holding territory, like Dawn of War, if Dawn of War allowed for massive troop counts on horrendously large maps.  It is however a large scale game designed to scale up with technology.  The two sides are also very different, so don't get bummed out that there are only two.

Dreadnoughts and Orbitals are the core of combat.

Dreadnoughts start out being able to wipe out horrendous amounts of troops, and they level up, gaining bonuses and special abilities, like armor piercing, self repair.  Much like Experimentals from Supreme Commander, they can seriously wreck the party.

Orbitals are one time ability purchases, that get more expensive every time you use them, paid for by a spammable income producing building that also pays for research upgrades.  They're a diverse array of impacts, from simple vision and dropping an engineer at a remote location, to fleet trashing orbital bombardment.

The rest of your power comes in the form of an excellent array of defensive structures, far less complicated than Supreme Commander, but very effective and very different between the two sides, and the fleets of frigates and cruisers you build up for the bulk of your forces.

It's an excellent strategy game, great for multiplayer, with game length and scope being highly variable from small maps to large ones.  The single player campaign isn't too great, more of a tutorial that pushes you to play different ways to accomplish your goals, but skirmishes are fantastic.  You can do anything from a short half hour game to a day long slog as you war your way across a massive arena.  At present I think Supreme Commander is still the better game, but engine wise there's simply no comparison to the scale of gameplay you can achieve, and the potential is there to dethrone it big time with the planned expansions and features Stardock has put out.  Odds are you can actually mod it into a better game already, and more capabilities are planned there as well.
