reviewText:
I purchased Ashes of the Singularity back when it was in Early Access, and I have so far been very impressed. Like many, I was looking for a successor to Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance. However, despite its apparent similarities, this is a very different game, and that is a good thing.

First off, above all else, this games strongest asset is Stardock. They are an amazing developer and their community involvement is superb. Constantly on the lookout for community feedback and addressing player concerns in the forums, they really care about their player base and making a good game. My appreciation for this aspect of their development process alone warrants this positive review, but it also helps that the game is also legitimately fun to play.

Turtling is a strategy that can often be a go-to for many players in RTS games, and to an extent, Ashes tries to make it a less-than-viable strategy. To win, you must accumulate resources, and to do this, you must exert as much control over as much of the map as possible. That being said, from beginning to end the game doesn't feel like a mad zerg rush to capture points, but more like you are waging a large-scale war on multiple fronts. The quanta resource mechanic is very interesting. You have your two main resources which are metal and radioactives which are used to construct units, where quanta is accumulated over time by constructing production buildings exclusively for that resource. Quanta can then be spent on anything from unit upgrades like health and damage to special abilities like calling in extra units or orbital strikes. Do you focus your resources entirely on unit production? Or do you bank on the long game by increasing the effectiveness of your units or maintaining a quanta reserve to blow on special abilities at critical moments?

I rarely write game reviews as I'm generally too lazy to put in the effort that I feel the games I love warrant. However, I made a special case for this game as I feel the developers deserve as much positive feedback as they can get. They have a passion for game development, and it shows. If you are looking for a unique large-scale strategy game and/or to support honest, genuine game developers, buy Ashes of the Singularity.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all, this review is coming from someone without any *major* RTS experience. I poured at least a couple hundred hours into Command and Conquer Generals and probably a hundred into AoE 3 back in the day, but other than that I guess you could call me an average player.

Second of all, the game's graphics are simply amazing especially when you have dozens of units fighting at the same time which does strain your system. With that being said, you better have a bangin' rig or else you might as well call this game Ashes of Microsoft PowerPoint because sometimes I’ll get ~15 FPS in HUGE firefights (30+ units).** However, don't be so worried if you're in the long run for the development of this game though. Based on what I've read, I believe Stardock is one of the few publishers you can trust to actually finish and present an optimized product. This isn't one of those Steam Early Access cash grab games developed by some guy in his mom's basement that leaves it to rot after a few months. It appears to me these developers actually have the resources to finish and update the game throughout its life cycle.

======

In this game, your objective is to capture generators throughout the map. I’m somewhat on the edge on this as I prefer a simpler RTS where the main objective is to just wipe out the enemy and win. It’s a faster pace game in the sense that you have almost “micro manage” your units to keep production and defend many generators at once. It’s a slower pace game in the sense that the units move very slowly from point A to B; which I’ll detail next.
To me, the units you control move a bit slower than I’d like. That isn’t necessarily a bad thing, but I’m much more used to faster paced RTS games. If that’s something you don’t like, they’ve recently updated the game as of today that increases a lot of different unit’s speed and there’s a lot of discussion in the community around the unit speeds that suggests even more change in the future.

Would I suggest this to a friend? Right now, probably not. Unless you know Stardock’s work, it’s hard to convince someone to cough up $40 (20% off sale right now) for a work in progress game. I don’t know if I suck, the AI are gods, or there’s a really high skill cap but I’m struggling to easily beat the “Easy AI” so I wouldn’t say this game is something you could just pick up and frag out on. If you want to be good, there’s a lot of stuff you have to learn otherwise you’re someone who’s neck deep in RTS.
If you’re someone who outright loves strategy games, Ashes of the Singularity is definitely an up and coming game. If you’re worried about it being an early access, unoptimized game (rightfully so) then keep it on your radar because I expect Ashes to be an even better game once they’ve fully finished the game.


**Running on GTX 780, i7-3770k, 8GB memory, installed on an SSD

reviewText:
Great game, fantastic engine that unlike my old favourite Supcom Forged Alliance, doesn't grind to a halt after an hour of play. You can have tons of units on a massive map all battling it out and it still runs smooth. It also looks beautiful.

The campaign is nothing to write home about and feels tacked on, however this game is all about multiplayer and skirmish. The AI is really good, my friends and I would fight against AIX Sorian in supcom and the Ashes AI is much better and more interesting to play against. Myself and two friends against several AI = hours of fun :)

Is it Forged Alliance or even Supcom 3? No it's not, it still needs unit balancing and more maps, but it's a fantastic RTS which is still getting regular updates from the devs. From what I understand it will continue to for the foreseeable future. It has a great core built on a really great engine and given the good on going work by devs is getting better and better.

The game is worth the money now and in a few more months will be so even more. If you like RTS this is a must for your library.

My top requests for this game in no particular order

More hot key controls for selecting units, e.g. in that other game" I like being able to press ctrl-z on a unit and have it select all units of that type. More ways of quickly moving units around the map

reviewText:
This is an amazingly good fun game for any RTS beginner or expert alike. It can be played at a steady pace of you can throw wave after wave -hey their disposable, sure it says so in the game.

This games draws a few things from some of the classics, Dawn of war and Company of hero's. Start on easy and enjoy the thrill of 3000 units worth of troops on a large(ish) map. Then play fast and furious.

The game is not without minor faults. Some times the difficulty goes from ridiculously easy   to unbelievably hard in the single player. I cannot find an option to set the level and this may put a lot of beginners off.

SOUND - the sound is all over the place some times. I turned the music down but the voice of the AI is quite often booming. But then in the rather nice looking cuts sequences, I strain to hear what they are even saying.

Game play is fluid but may get a little jerky near the end of the game with thousands (YES Thousand of units worth of troops). There is some optimization to be done I am sure after a few months it could well be smooth like butter, Which is how I like to defeat my enemy.

The AI is really good but sometimes just crushes you, till you get the hang of the game.
The visuals are pretty good but come on if you're admiring them that much 40 enemy units have passed you by and are at your base ( Muhahah).

The single player campaign is way too short for my liking I was expecting 12 to 15 PER faction but we got 12 and that was it.

The Dev's seem to be very active and they are adding things to this area, extra play modes etc. So things can only get better. Well apart from the enemy things look pretty bleak for them.

Hardware wise this can be a hard hitter but there are handy indicators to give you a clue. It doesn't say CRAZY on the preset for nothing and will take 10 - 15 fps. This can be the difference between playable and a jerk fest. But you are going to try it once- why because there is a big phrase in the middle and it says benchmark and you will want to try this.

However there are enough tabs in the setting to fine tune the graphics setting so no worries there.

If you are a RTS head this is the kind of game you will come back too time and again. I am a tiny bit addicted to it at the moment and seem to have at least 4 or 5 games spread out during the day.

I started playing on easy and watched the AI on my team build up, it is a really good way to learn the in's and outs of the game. SO my advice if your new to this play the tutorial and then start a 4 player 2 vs 2 AI and watch your AI team mate and you will soon get the hang of it. IF you have played some of the other top RTS game then you pretty much know how to play this already.

Last but not least - Don't go easy the enemy had it coming - honest guv.

Early Access Review

At first i didnt like it and thought about returning it. But this is one of those games where the more you play, the more you love it. First off, i LOVE the UI. Its not ugly nor is it hard to navigate. I love all the different colors in the UI and find it easy to find what im looking for. Second, the meta-unit army thing is really the best thing about this game. Ive always hated microing my units during battles. All i want to do is select a glob of units and tell em to attack. All the unit micro is handled in this game which allows you to have multiple massive battles across the map. The medics will go heal any unit in the army and the artillery units stay in the back. Its soo great not having to micro all that. Third, if you loved Sins (i do) then you will love this game. Instead of planets you get power generators to capture which have resource plots connected to said generators. Fourth, its NOT supcom 3! The only thing this game has that is similar to supcom is the emphasis on massive battles. That stupid economy in supcom FA is NOT in this game.  Fifth, battles can range from tiny maps to massive ones. So if you just want to pop in and play a match for a half hour you can or if you want to sit and have a massive hour or 2 hour long war with some buddies you can.

Now for the bad stuff:
1) I would like 1 more faction. Im ok with just 2 but id like at least 1 more.
2) Needs a few more units for each faction

I would have to say that im going to playing a LOT of this game and that ive just deleted supcom FA because of this game. One of the best ground based RTS games ive played in a while. id have to give it a 9/10.

reviewText:
Supreme Commander and Sins of A Solar Empire have a baby, and the result is Ashes of the Singularity. What a title.

Ashes is an RTS that consists of massive scale battles on several maps, that vary in size, and up to 6 players (With it being extended to 12) These maps take place on several types of planets, and majority of them are designed extremely well. The object of the game is simple: Mass an army of hundreds of units, potentially thousands, and go wreak havoc upon your enemies. Does the game require strategy? Yes, to a certain degree, although that could be improved.

You could say the game is basic in It's approach, and it is, but It's extremely fun.

There are currently two Factions, with a third incoming. PHC = Pro-Human Coalition. Substrate = Sentient A.I.

Each of these two factions play very differently from each other, with unique unit/structure designs to their own. While slightly generic, they each have some cool units that do standout, including my personal favourite ZUES for the PHC which shoots out a lightning arc, covering a wide area in front of it.

Each factions has the following number of Units/Structures. PHC = 4 Frigates, 4 Cruisers, 3 Aircraft and 3 Dreadnaughts. 4 main unit structures that don't require any sort of Tier upgrades. Substrate consist of the same amount of units, but they play differently to PHC, with their own set of structures and requirements.

The game also has several defenses for both factions. Smarties, which are rocket batteries and target light air units and ground units. Sensor Arrays, Anti-Air, Drone Bays, Repair Bay and Turrets, which are effective towards Dreadnaughts.

A total of 6 Orbitals, each of them completely different. You have Incursion Orbitals, consistent drop of turrets, Amplifiers, EMP, Jammers/Nullifiers (Which disable the use of Orbtials) and the Orbital Strike.

Support Abilities being a total of 4, and 5 Offensive Abilities. The game also has upgrades that increase unit damage, unit health and also resource management, such as increasing total unit count, Metal and Radioactives.

Each faction employs different strategies, and while there is currently only two, both are fun to play, and the third should be no different.

Now onto the PROS and CONS for Ashes of the Singularity (In My Own Personal Opinion)

PROS:

+ Two Factions that plays different from each other.
+ Some of the best A.I I've come to experience from an RTS game (It simply doesn't Cheat" and that's wonderful)
+ Good unit designs
date: especially for the Dreadnaughts.\n+ Great number of maps

reviewText: If you're a fan of flashy unit skins and unending actions per minute, this is not your game. If, like me, your reaction speeds hurt your modern RTS playing, welcome to the game for you. I'm a huge fan of turn-based strategy specifically because of the lack of focus on instantaneous micromanagement. Ashes has a similar feel, where the responsiveness of the bulkiest units requires you to plan ahead. The focus on flooding the map with units also moves the focus away from micromanagement to a more-traditional grand strategy approach of attacks, counterattacks, and contingency plans. I'd say this is an RTS for the TBS crowd, and I personally love it.

CONS: Mostly cosmetic and GUI related

In short: Do buy this game if you are on the fence. Its fantastic and might just end up being AMAZING in the coming months.

reviewText:
I like more macro focused RTS's, and this game really fills that niche for me. Huge armies duking it out with lots of particle effects, and the occasional orbital ability. Managing what you bring to a fight and the route that it's going to take matters more than exact positioning or trying to get of an ability in a given split second.

Likes: the economy and army system emphasises map control. Unit rosters are reasonably diverse, and the races themselves handle differently. Orbital abilites are strong, and can really impact the flow of the game, but often aren't an automatic win on their own.

Problems: there's still some balance issues, as the different unit rosters means that sometimes it's really not easy to respond to something if you're PHC or Substrate. Defense are generally pretty poor, and combined with the strong focus on map control it's basically impossible to turtle without lossing really fast. Even trying to use defenses to stall often doesn't work. The deve's are working on all of this, including putting some new units into the game (for free), but at the moment it's still present.

Also, a bunch of features that are promised haven't been implemented yet. Spectator mode, for instance.

Early Access Review

This game is a very large scale and fun RTS. Thier are multiple ways to wage war, not battles mind you, accros the giant maps they provide. When i first bought this game I refunded it due to the lack of having any sort of tutorial. I have rebought this game, before they even fully released a main tutorial, and found multiple guides made by the dev's online on how to play. This game is very fun and addictive; Now down to the pro's and con's.

Pro's:
Lots of massive battles, all going on at once, just like a war should be.

Con's:
some minor and major glitches (most of these dont make the game unplayable, but their is one Texture glitch that can happen that will stop rendering the correct colors) Yet we cant hold this against them as this is a game in beta. NOT ONLY THAT but the glitches they find are normaly quickly patched.
Somewhat hard to find a multiplayer game sometimes due to the lack of people, but this is less of a con and more of another beta effect


So overall as it is in its current development, i'll give Ashes Of The Singularity an 8/10, on full release of content this review will be rewriten and most likely given an even higher score.

reviewText:
I really love this game.  Finally a game which does not rely on the number of clicks per second you can perform.  Build your units, assign it to an army at the click of a button and tell your army where to go.  Your army will form up, stick together and adjust the formation to position units where they should be for maximum effect.  A good example of this is the basics frigates, one of which is meant to be used as cannon fodder; they will move between your army and any aggressor to protect the more valuable units.

There are 3 tiers of ground units; Frigates, Cruisers (?) and Dreadnoughts.  Each tier has a range of units to provide different tactical options. Frigates include the cannon fodder I mentioned earlier, a rocket launcher, medic and scout.  Cruisers include artillery, anti-air, anti-dreadnought and brawler.  Dreadnoughts come in 3 flavors; anti-dreadnought, anti-buildings and another brawler.

Dreadnoughts can be upgraded with abilities which are shared across it's designated army.  From shields to extra firepower there are many to choose from, or you could sacrifice a level upgrade to repair your entire fleet.

Air unit selection is rather lacking with a scout, anti-air and anti-ground units.  The bombers (anti-ground) are very effective when used in large numbers and can be extremely difficult to defend against large numbers as they can quickly destroy anti-air defences.  Some more powerful anti-air defences would be nice to make anti-air defences more potent, though at the time of review bombers are quite expensive to build (in their defence).

I've worked my way through the majority of the campaign (just one left, unless the Dev's add any more).  There has been some criticism against the single player.  Yes, there are no voiceovers and the mission objectives are relayed over to your via text.  Sometimes you could accidently skip over these communication text messages, as they pop up in the corner of the screen and dismissed by clicking any button, which when you are clicking to give orders for armies or build queues you could potentially dismiss them before you noticed them.

The missions themselves are fun and slowly introduce new tech as you progress, just as you expect from an RTS.  Some side missions open up the tech tree more than on the main story, which is a little baffling.  You are given a range of new toys that won’t be explained until you head further through the main branch of the campaign.

When it comes to the introductions, some of the explanations of the tech are also easily misunderstood.  For example you can add an amplifier on a resource node (for collecting metal or radiation, your primary construction resources).  Then activate an ability on the amplifier to increase the income rate of the resource.  I totally miss understood and just built the amplifier, unaware of the orbital ability until I noticed it in another mission.  It's not a major gripe; it just meant I learnt how to use that technology a little later than the game perhaps expected me to have.

Overall, as I started this review I really love this game.  I have been mostly playing skirmish against the AI to improve my skills and knowledge and have enjoyed being blown up by Human opponents whom are more knowledgeable than myself.  I will be looking forward to applying my new commander skills against the Humans, having now being able to handle myself against a normal AI opponent.

reviewText:
Enjoy Real Time Strategy (RTS) games?
Enjoy controlling a large army?
Love lasers?
Then this is the game for you!

This game brings back feelings of old style RTS games. Capture generators to produce more resources and make large scale armies to overwhelm your enemy. Battles are at are a huge scale with fantastic looking graphics. Sound design is also amazing and matches with the theme perfectly.

There isn't a huge variety of units and there is only 2 factions at the moment but I have heard that more are being added. There are some bugs and balance issues at the moment, but they are being fixed. But these things don't take away from gameplay at all.

Overall, this game brings back memories of old RTS games and you should definitely buy it if you are a fan of RTS games as a whole

reviewText:
Early Access Review

[Please note that this copy was provided to me free of cost for review.]
Overview: I recommend this game for RTS fans and I personally think that the finished game will be great.
https://youtu.be/hwHtSRJKfvE
Ashes of the Singularity is a pre beta real time strategy game from Oxide Games and Stardock Entertainment.  You build a base of operations and conquer the battlefield to gather resources with which you construct a massive fleet of units to clash with your opponents.  It reminds me a lot of the Supreme Commander games as well as the Command and Conquer games.
The battles commonly involve a very large number of units and the upper hand can be lost in a single bad move.  There is a wide variety of units, upgrades, and buildings available and more are going to be added before the full release.  There are singleplayer as well as online multiplayer matches.  This game is a lot of fun even though it is unfinished and I think that it is currently a very solid foundation on which a great game will be built.

The balance of factions is spot on, after many ranked matches it is clear that the strategic decisions decide your strength, not the strength of the units themselves. If you've had the itch since the old C&C days, this will scratch it.

reviewText: All in all this is a fun game. It is like Supreme Commander but with a whole lot of the things SupCom:FA does wrong fixed. No more pointless tiers of both units and extractors that exist solely to pad out the game and make it longer than it has to be. The stuff you're building from the start are units you will be using throughout, so nothing goes obsolete other than what your opponent counters. It's a very strategic game.\nIt's not perfect though. Factions are so all-around that most matches feel like you're both just doing the exact same thing and there's nothing with some real game-changing power to it. Nothing with the impact of well placed Siege Tanks from Brood War. The slower pace both makes even slower players able to react, but on the other hand it makes everyone able to react. The upside is easier to play for people who aren't as fast, the downside is this means it's very much a numbers game. Very few surprises makes the games fairly predictable.\nIf you like big RTS games or just RTS games in general, definitely buy this one. It's the best one of its sort coming out for a long time. If you think RTS are just who-can-click-fastest competitions, well first of all you're bad at video games and second of all this game might be your type of thing. Though if you exclusively play EU or HoI then you'll get as stomped in this game as in any other RTS, because it's not slow to the point where you can go afk for a few minutes and come back without having lost.

reviewText:
Pros:
- Fun mechanics to learn and play around with
- Solid base building
- Economy balancing with unit and structure build prioritising keeps me focused on expanding rapidly with care
- AI for my experience is the best in the genre, no cheating, just straight up fair tough challenge - player unit AI behaves really well for the most part too
- Aesthetically pleasing unit design and weaponry
- Large scale battles that require planning a few steps ahead
- Army compositions play a huge part in being successful and I am having fun finding the sweet spot for various situations that a single game presents (early-mid-late)
- Performs well on my laptop (XPS 15 9550) with about 40fps @ 1080p low settings
- Theme and story is minimal in design and implementation but floats the game perfectly.

Cons:
- Sound design is average for my taste, not annoying at but lacking something I can't quite get my ears around
- Alert to let you know when your armies and bases are engaged would be a great addition for my laid back approach to being a general.

I am yet to try MP and likely won't - I like relaxing with these types of games and I look forward to being part of this regularly updated gem of an RTS.

9/10

reviewText:
Sins of a Solar Empire met with the the good old Total Annihilation formula (though tactics-wide it's mostly Sins, just with power nodes instead of planets and drones instead of fighters, basically everything is the same except there are no titans and stations... yet) and a great game engine which finally doesn't slow down, crashes, whatsoever when pushed to the limits. Plus you have an insanely good micromanaging AI so no more wasted time on unnecessary clicking just to stop artys making rush moves inside a formation. Even if you send your units through a bottleneck, they make a circle just to take the optimal form and composition to fit through it not unlike in most other RTS where they just make a cluster♥♥♥♥ of random units bumping on each other. The DX12 support can be described best just like: +15 FPS on max graphics. The weak spot of the game is the mediocre Campaign (more like an extended tutorial), but Sins didn't even have one and well... who cared. The other is the kind of bare maps mostly due to the lack of water warfare. Most of the difference comes from the node linkings (Sins again... without space that is). And we're still waiting for the 3rd faction... on the other hand: I can't wait to see what the modders can do with this engine because Sins had great ones but every one of them hit the cap of the engine fast with memory and threading issues. Not to mention Supreme Commander where you get a 1/10 simulation slowdown even with the vanilla game.

Cons:
The explosions are kind of boring though, because there are no wrecks but devs've made some posts how the engine could handle it so I'm looking forward to see falling plane wreckages all around like in SupCom.
Still lacking some controls, like different army type selection.
Music is so-so... Sins has great diverse tracks but it's like SupCom: a few let's just say
date: ok" tracks here and there but they get old fast.\n\nWe'll see how they're going to patch up this game like the've done with most of their previous titles."

reviewText: When I first got this game, my expectations were high. It looked and sounded amazing. The game downloaded, and I played it. I was amazed by the graphics, because they were better than anything I had expected. I played the game, and at first I was dissapointed. I thought that it was fun, but not better than the game Planetary Annahilation, and definitely not worth the $60 price tag. I played it a bit more, however, and discovered that it is much more fun than Planetary Annahilation. Although it does not have spherical maps, nuclear weapons, or planet destroying lasers, it has better AI than any strategy game I have ever played. It's large-scale battles are unlike anything I have ever seen In PA. Also, it has a fun campaign.

reviewText:
Ashes of the Singularity overall is a very good RTS which has made great progress from alpha stages to now (it's official release). I find the game excellent and have had fun playing it being an avid RTS fan, and have to say, I haven't been left dissapointed.

Gameplay: The gameplay is good, Units and factions are nicely balanced with exceptionally nice visuals. Overall, myself and a group of friends have had hours of fun playing against each other and against the AI. There's room for improvement but that can be said for any game but the devs have outlined that further improvements are coming and the game with further be refined and tweaked which is great news to hear.

The soundtrack for this game and the sound/SFX is exceptional, one of the best sound expereiences in any game and certainly the best I've heard in an RTS. the sound and music really draws you into the game, loving it.

Now, this may not be vital to some but for me it was a breath of fresh air that the developers are great on comminicating with their customers, the community. Throughout the development they were in constant communication with the community asking for feedback, getting feedback and implementing the feedback into the game. Absolutely top notch support from these guys and they provided tons of info, roadmaps and update info. Don't take my word for it check out the steam forums.

Overall I'm happy with the game and have not been left dissapointed. Like I said there is room for improvement and with the developers actively talking to the community getting feedback and basically asking what we want I think this is a great recipe for further improements down the road. I'm a happy customer and happier with the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ashes of the Singularity aims ambitiously to take the best parts of all the other great RTS games that have been released over the years - Total Annihilation, Planetary Annihilation, Supreme Commander, Sins of a Solar Empire and StarCraft (just to name a few) - and produce a brainchild that has the potential to grow up to become the biggest and brightest RTS commercially available.

Although it is missing alot given its current state and stage of development, this game is already entertaining and proves to have a very promising future thanks to the enthusiasm of the developers and the active community that contribute toward the development of the game.

Me myself am looking forward to the interplanetary combat, as I'm intrigued as to how that might play out, along with some smaller features such as implementing new gameplay elements - such as broader research/diplomacy, devastating endgame weapons, etc. without the necessity for micromanaging (which I hope is the ambition of the game :D) - more open-ended maps (being able to go from one point to the other, say if it were a planetary map - if there will be any others :/), and of course - hopefully - hardware optimisation :).

Being a complete noob to the game, and already being pretty bad at RTS games, I can happily say that the AI is already difficult (even on low difficulties!) which I find somewhat humiliating but also refreshing knowing that I can play offline mode expecting a challenge if I want one, so good job to the programmers there.

Despite the lack of hardware optimisation, the beauty of the game is not faultered by my laptop's inability to run it at a particularly eye-popping quality, and given that the game is in the early stage of development, I can only expect it to look even better as time goes on.

The battle maps are fairly basic when it comes to the natural environment and atmosphere, but given that the game is about fighting over that very land, it can't be a surprise as to why that is the case.

The developers are really committed to listening to what the community has to say about the game - what the game is lacking, what the game could incorporate from other inspirations, what ideas the community has theirselves, etc. - which is really promising when it comes to determining the future of the game, since the game will of course be the brainchild of the community's and the developer's ideas and implementations, which should bring fans as close as they can get to help make the game the game that they really want to play - after paying £40 for it :D.

Personally, I'm really looking forward to what this game can become :).


*P.S.   Sorry about not reviewing the multiplayer part - the gameplay is essentially the same as playing solo just that you're playing against opponents that have even more initiative than the AI do, which is bad news for me :D. - I'll build slow and die fast, since I'm quite helpless without my SupCom base shields :D. I didn't come round to testing it out because of this, sorry about that :/.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What's here so far is absolutely fantastic, with the promise of much more in the future.

For an early access, it's very stable and I haven't had any complications from bugs or crashes.  Updates are usually pretty spaced out, but they're usually big and include more than just bug fixes.

The skirmish Ai is probably the best I've played against in a long time in any RTS game, which makes each and every game an enjoyable experience.  This is the highlight of the game for me so far.

As for what the actual gameplay is like, it's very  reminiscent of Supreme Commander while having enough innovation that it doesn't feel derivative.   The region system both adds focal points for conflict, while encouraging strategy on a macro level.  The army system makes controlling hundreds of units both intuitive and easy, while at the same time emphasising unit composition and ability.  The upgrades and special abilities demand some thought as the both pull from the same resource pool, and in some cases will permanently increase in cost through the course of the game.

The graphics are top shelf and large battles are fun and exciting to watch play out.

A word of warning though, if you prefer fast pace, or micro intensive RTS's, then this game is not for you.  This game is about slowly building momentum until you roll over your opponent.

reviewText:
It's worth it.


My very own subjective impressions as casual/occasional/mediocre strategy game player, who likes good graphics:


Plays well. Not as hectic as Planetary Annihilation. I like it's pace so far.
Also it's less complicated with a decent amount of units. (I don't need 100 different units with 70% just being upgraded tier ones)
Just enough to let you have the clue about them quickly and focus more on the strategy and where to send them.
I'm not immediately lost in a choice of hundreds of units which makes it really accessible for new players. Upgrading is linear and has a small depth which is also good.
The units organize themselves well enough to have less micro management.
I just like how to claim the map and how it's devided in zones to give you a quick overview of your control within a second of looking at the map.
In general it just feels good to me. Definetly one of those games I'd rather start when I'm bored that doesn't turn me off by thinking of playing it like Evolve which I like but where I just feel to bad to even start it online fearing to become the monster and get my ♥♥♥ kicked right away.
AI feels also fair ... though I only played on easy so far and won with a massive army. It tested and found my weakpoints after some time.
From the design of the connection of those points I'd assume that I could cut off parts of the enemies eco when capturing points in the middle of his territory. (It does!)
Graphics are good enough. I like the particle effects of the projectiles. The explosions of dreadnaughts not as much.
Lightning could be more dramatic. It looks kinda flat which is nice for strategy but not if you're seeking for nice graphics.
Freesync works well with it.

The soundtrack is good. Wide, open, slow but dramatic orchestral. I like the battle soundtracks and the transition between soundtracks is also smooth. No Hi-Res though. (ogg 350kb/s 44khz)
Soundeffects are also good. Lasers remember me of star wars. The explosions should be more dramatic/satisfying.
The voice acting is not that good.

Loadtimes are incredibly fast. I installed it on my SSD and a 1v1 AI skirmish loads within 3sec.

reviewText:
If you like epic RTSs (Supreme Commander, Total Annihilation, Homeworld), this is the game for you.  It may be lacking in a few areas, but that just means the makers have room to improve.

With the little time I have spent in the game (~5 hours), I have noticed a few things.  The game itself has a lot of potential to fill that gap we all need ... the slightly slower paced but more satisfying RTS experience on a larger scale.  However, I think there is still room for improvement in some areas as well as a few suggestions I have.

Pros:
+Large maps.
+Big fights.
+Fun end-game units.
+Great music.  Need more of this!

Cons:
-Little story.
-Little to no voice acting, especially from the units.  And the sound quality for them seems to be very low and no variety in their response to commands... just the same bleep bloop sound they make.
-Although I understand the game is still in its infancy, there are not very many units, buildings, or factions to choose from in the game.
-No variation in formations once a group has been made into an army. (Take examples from the Supreme Commander or Homeworld series)

Suggestions:
*I am not sure if modding of the game is allowed, but if the makers let the community expand the game themselves with their ideas by creating new maps and new units, the makers could benefit from this.
*More unit variety and specializations.
*Expand on the veterancy of all units rather than just Dreadnaughts (examples from Supreme Commander series and Red Alert 2) reinforcing the idea of keeping your units alive through multiple battles instead of throwing them at a wall.
*More voice acting!  Especially from the units themselves.
*More formations to choose from within armies.
*Ability to split an army group in half (or as best as you can) to make multiple groups comprised of the same types and numbers of units in a hurry.
*A technology wing or research building to specialize in to adapt to your enemies strengths and weaknesses.
*More early-to-midgame units.
*Even larger maps!

I enjoy the game as of right now, but would love to see improvement.

reviewText:
3 hours in, and here are my first impressions:

TL;DR worth the purchase price IF you can run it.

They tried to slow down the RTS pace a bit, and make it more RTS than RT-CLICKCLICKCLICKCLICKCLICKDAMMIT!

They (mostly) succeeded!

You have to make decisions about how you want armies to move significantly in advance of when you actually plan on having them arrive, most fights seem to be for incremental advances to avoid overextending yourself, and unless your opponent bottlenecks their economy early on (which is easy to do if you're not paying attention, I'll admit) it's unlikely to be an out-and-out steamroll. Zerg-rushing really doesn't work very well, since the primary base for each faction can actually defend itself. All in all this portion of the gameplay is excellent.

The tech tree is split into a few parts. Different units and buildings follow the normal progression (Building X is required for Unit X, Y for Y, etc.), but unit, logistical, and economic upgrades all fall under the same resource (called Quanta). When you have enough Quanta for the upgrade, just click on it and it instantly applies. I can't strictly say I'm a tremendous fan of that particular mechanic, BUT they added a twist to it that I genuinely do enjoy. In addition to using Quanta for upgrades, you can use it for one-off effects like calling down an orbital strike, small units, sensor sweeps, etc. I personally think this is an excellent tradeoff. It gives you the ability to think on the fly a bit, and adds a lot more tactical flexibility that the game would otherwise lack. I'd call this part of things good, but I still don't particularly like that instant gratification research system. Maybe tying the upgrades to when a dreadnought levels (allowing them to apply the upgrade to the army they're leading) so it isn't automatic would be better.

Unit diversity is a bit... lacking visually. I understand the reasoning, but honestly it's difficult to tell what a unit's function is at a glance. Once you know what each unit does it's fine, but truth be told I'm not a fan of the designs overall. That said, when large armies clash it is visually spectacular. Laser, plasma, missiles, bombs, and slugs go flying around and just look cool. I'm guessing this is why the designs look so basic/indistinct. If each unit was highly detailed it'd probably be a graphics card melter. I do still think it could have been done a lot better.

The maps are likewise incredibly bland. They look alright as long as you don't zoom in on them, but holy mother of god they're oogly up close. This, in my opinion, is the weakest part of the game by a wide margin.

The super-units, dreadnoughts, are distinct, visually interesting, and generally a lot of fun. They've each got their own niches, but all of them are absolute beasts without being unkillable. Proper army composition is more important than raw numbers to a large degree, and moving these things at the center of a force that you're sending in to annihilate your enemy is tons of fun to watch.

The economy of the game is more complex than it first appears. Each unit requires 2 or 3 resources to construct: Logistics, Metal, and Radioactive Materials. You can store only limited amounts of each, but the overall capacity can be increased with Quanta. You collect these resources by constructing collectors on nodes which will require a consistent supply line back to your home base. Once it's built, you get the resource at a fixed (but slightly upgradeable) rate. This means that prioritizing construction of units, buildings, and resource development is a must. This is also where the bulk of the game's micromanagement comes in. Defending your supply chains is VITAL, and losing a single node in a key place can cripple your economy. Setting up an attack at one of these chokepoints is awesome if you can pull it off.

The only bug I've seen is that it tends to crash when you click Done" after a skirmish.

Overall
date: my opinion is pretty positive. The game's got a few mild annoyances
recommended: but at the same time is a really well done strategy game. It's hurt by the lack of a co-op campaign
hoursPlayed: visual style complaints (which I'll admit are subjective and possibly justified)
voteText:
and a "meh" soundtrack. It's well worth purchasing IF you're rocking the necessary hardware.

Specs of my PC:

Intel core i7 5820 (OC'd to 4 ghz)
16 gigs DDR4 2666
GTX 980 card
running from a samsung 850pro SSD
Windows 7"

reviewText:
If you like Supreme Commander 2 then you will like this game. If Starcraft 2 is too fast paced for you then you will enjoy this game.

Ashes of the Singularity is a real time strategy game with a greater emphasis on macro rather than micro. Although map control is crucial to victory (more regions controlled = more resource income), that alone may not be enough as incorrect army/unit positioning may be the factor that decides who wins and who loses.

By the way, even if you control most of the map, your opponent can cut off your supply if they neutralize one (or more) of the regions in your supply chain.

The campaign: Treat it like an extended tutorial. It shows you a variety of scenarios where you can see the most effective use of different units. Aside from that, there is nothing special about the campaign.

Personally, I play the game for the skirmish and multiplayer as that is where the real fun is :P

The game does have some annoying issues. There are times when you would like to separate a unit from your army but it is hard to do so (need to disband army first, then individually select the unit).
Very large army groups will spread out over an unnecessarily large area before moving out, resulting in some units in the army group moving away from the destination to some arbitrary point in the middle of the army before moving forward; that movement could cost valuable travel time especially when you are reacting to an incursion force.

Although there are issues that need to be addressed, the developers frequently check the forums and engage with the community. As a result, the game is constantly improving with each update (new units, more scenarios and longer campaign are being hinted at).

Give it some time and the game will be worth the price. Or wait for sale. Or wait until the game becomes more polished. Regardless, in my opinion, the game is fun to play as it is and it will get better as time goes by.

reviewText:
I've seen a lot of people who are frustrated that Ashes is an old-feeling, macromanagement RTS. My heart goes out to them, but I absolutely love this game. There are a couple things that bug me (No crossfire on Windows 7, inconsistant difficulty) but watching your hordes clash against the enemy, while Dreadnaughts pelt the battlefield is so much fun to set up.

And while some may prefer Starcraft's style of gameplay, Ashes slower, more methodical pace is exactly what I look for in an RTS. The game doesn't care about your APM (Hell, you can pause and give commands), it cares about your long-term planning.

Couldn't be happier with the game.

reviewText:
Did you like Supreme Commander's scale of battles but long for more? Ashes of the Singularity might be right up your alley.
https://youtu.be/S6v_wHdSBCU

At it's core, the game is a solid RTS, and pretty well fleshed out. It has the campaign, skirmish modes, and multiplayer (complete with ranked matches). All the boxes checked for what you want in terms of game modes.  But how is the game itself?

Well, I'd say overall it compares at a pretty even level with other good titles out there, such as the previously mentioned Supreme Commander.
That's not calling it average or mediocre though. The game is well polished, and plays well. It's a good sign of a game when you actually struggle to find things that annoy you or were tedious. Ashes is overall a pretty smooth experience, and for experienced RTS players, it's not hard to jump right into it.

The universal upgrade system is a bit of an interesting direction, as you don't need to build up buildings to research upgrades. In fact, there's no real tech tree to speak of at all, just upgrades.

Speaking of buildings, don't be expecting to build up massive bases like in some other RTS games out there. No sir. Buildings in general -while important- seem to take a back seat to combat.

Make no mistake about it, the large scale battles are what Ashes is banking on, and it is something it pulls off beautifully. Quite amazing to watch, really; with missiles, drones, lasers, and you name-it flying all over the battlefield, massive amounts of units moving in formations... the intensity really ramps up when combat starts.
You'll actually find yourself wanting to build up a massive amount of units just to throw them all into another fight.

Some of the small touches are nice too, for example the big dreadnaughts gain experience from combat and can unlock some near game-changing abilities.
Also the unit variety, while not earth-shattering, is plenty to have something for most any situation.


Sound is decent, there are times where the little computer lady talking to me would blurt out stuff I could barely understand, but otherwise the little alert noises, music, and -of course- explosions seemed adequate.

Visually the game is good. I'm talking about the graphics themselves, not watching everything unravel on a battlefield-wide scale. The units are interesting looking, detailed, and can be quite colorful depending on your player color. More so than a lot of other RTS games. Scenery around looks pretty nice, though there are some times when I had to look again to make sure things hadn't frozen. If you don't have units moving around, it's an easy mistake to make, as the buildings themselves are basically static.

I won't say everything is sunshine and roses though. There's a few things that I find a bit bland or unpleasant.

For starters, I'm not a fan of the lines connecting every resource point. It's strange, and it takes away any sense of maybe I can hide a small factory up on this hillside to prep an ambush and they'll not notice me." Nope
recommended: there's a frikkin LINE drawn straight to every resource node.  No secrets there.\n\nSince you're just some commander in charge of a bunch of units
hoursPlayed: there's not much personality or character to things. Nothing to really draw you in. You're not going to be screaming "Johnny NOOOOOOOooooo!" When your favorite dreadnaught gets blown up
voteText:
you're just going to build another one. (If you haven't already.)

It would also be nice to see some more skirmish or multiplayer maps that weren't just symmetrical.

Most of my complaints are fairly minor things though
helpfulPercent: and do little to detract from the game overall.\n\nI've enjoyed the game a lot thus far
votesHelpful:
and expect I will continue to enjoy it a lot longer. I'd recommend picking it up if you're a fan of the Total Annihilation or Supreme Commander style RTS games.

TLDR?
It's fun
votesTotal: it's pretty
votesFunny: and it's got a bit of the "wow" factor. It's good."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I see what they are striving for and I am excited to see the final implementation.

The main issue I've seen thus far has been with the army system.  You're supposed to be able to order reinforcements, yet it's horribly buggy.  I am sure they are aware and have either fixed or plan to fix it.

There are certainly some balance issues with this game.  The 2 foremost are artillery and healing.  There should be a defensive structure that gives a bubble shield specifically for dealing with artillery or some such counter to artillery.  As of right now the artillery dreadnaught of the PHC can level a base using it's long range cannons and by investing in the radar upgrade.  Healing is a major concern.  Substrate cannot heal.  This makes their dreadnaughts pointless.  Great, you've gotten to level 5.  It has 10 health left.  Now what?

Regardless of this, it's a solid RTS that is rather fun.  You can get locked into long beautiful battles repeatedly in a game and I find this is what a wargame should be all about.  If you enjoy RTS even a little bit, pick this title up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I found Ashes of the Singularity generally boring. It's true that this game is currently going through a beta phase, and the full game is not expected for a while, but as it stands it's not really doing anything to captivate my interest. A Beta is not an Alpha, meaning that major gameplay changes are unlikely to be made before actual release. Ill tell you what I liked and dislike as I go along. But the major down sides were the line system, the boring nature of the units, and the overly neat command of mass paired units. I didn't like the character of the buildings or the actual maps themselves, and to me the game was overly refined.

============================

Firstly, I thought the HUD system in Ashes was amazing, probably one of the best I've ever seen, and that is, until I actually played Homeworld Deserts of Kharak. Battlefield wise, I didn't like that the far zooming option wasn't there. I really like my tactical long distance view, but in this game you can't go up sky high and watch things unfold. Sadly zooming deeply into a units wasn't available either making your connection to individual ships and the overall experience of big battles less personal and immersive. The unit AI is a little bit too intuitive, and so is the build structure order, the whole process comes off as a bit predefined and lacking substance. Everything flows too well together, the units fold in perfectly, the trajectories of particles falls where it should and you’d think that’s perfect right? Sadly it was lacking that chaotic feel of micro managing everything, and having things miss sometimes. I seldomly ever had to micro anything and I also felt like that took away from the experience. I didn't like the line build system, man I REALLY didn’t like the line build system, it felt very outdated and unnecessary. The units also didn't captivate me, they seemed repetitive in design and nature. The effects were pretty, but not as pretty as Deserts of Kharak. The map design was lacking allot of character, as the maps seemed very generic and lacking realism. I wasn’t excited to scroll through the map list, and I never really cared about the backstory of any of the multiplayer maps, it just didn’t feel “cool” to be there. The Air units felt a little bit silly, especially as they were aimlessly circling my base, at one point I was hoping they would hover? The pirates protecting metal nodes were fun, but they had no real reason to be there, and they weren't diverse in nature. In Sins of the Solar Empire the pirates are inhabitants of the planets, the second you go into their system they attack you for crossing into their territory, in this? Well, they are there just because. I get that they want to control base expansion speeds, but why not have some back story and life behind those pirates. It felt like too much of a copy paste job, just because. The detection system, fog of war and unit vision was excellent. Unit response was impeccable. The structures looked dull, and lacking that “cool” or “I actually care about this building” feeling. In conclusion it's a waiting game with Ashes, but at the moment I’d rather play Homeworld Deserts of Kharak -- by far. These two titles are galaxies apart and I mean that literally. Ashes feels like a rip of many games, it doesn’t feel like there is enough unique character in this game. Being a DX 12 RTS game is cool, but that’s about the only thing that’s really going for this title.

If you want your fills, just get a cheap version of Supreme Commander 2, It's honestly all you need.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Good

It's Amazing You Should Buy It

Do you like Sins of a Solar Empire? Then you'll like this. It has the same epic feel and amazing graphics if you have the ridiculous hardware required to support it. I sat down expecting to peruse the early access and move on. Two hours later I was still playing and only stopped only because I realized I do indeed have work in the morning.

The Bad

Prepare your hardware's perverbial ♥♥♥♥♥♥ because the high computing penetration is about to begin. I normally run games on max graphics or close to it. Ya. Anything higher than low was a total no go.

The Semi-Relevant

As an added bonus it actually uses more than one core... you know... so it actually can run... *cough* *cough* unlike certain other aforementioned Stardock games whose epic feel may or may not be diminished because the game can't handle rendering more than 5 ships at a time without exploding. So despite being one of the best games of all time, it's a useless turd. This game doesn't do that, which is a pretty big bonus.

reviewText:
The game seems to take a lot of ideas from Supreme Commander, which in my opinion, is probably the best RTS to take pointers from if you are trying to create one based around massive scale combat. This game has some really large scale battles I will give it that, but it isn't without its flaws

The game lacks some basic functionality that could really push it over the edge into being a great game. For example, you can create 'armies'. This is the same as in many other games where you create control groups and can simply press the button assigned to that army to instantly select all units within it. The problem is, it feels as if the game considers enemy armies one unit. So when you tell your units to attack an enemy, they will attack whatever enemy is closest. This means you cannot focus fire enemy units. If there is a repair drone repairing your enemy's units? Well, you're just going to have to hope that your units hurry up and chew through the front lines of your opponent's forces because that's the only way they will target the drones, is when they get to them.

The game's ranked matchmaking also seems to not have a clue what it's doing. At rank 8 (I believe there are only 10 ranks) I was matched against a rank 4 player. Without knowing too terribly much of what I was doing, I was completely destroyed and didn't stand a chance. Next game was a similar match up and then I simply gave up.

The units are also lacking in diversity. You essentially have your tech 1 units, tech 2 units, and tech 3 units, for those Supreme Commander fans out there. What this means is, you will start by building frigates. These are the cheapest most basic units. You will quickly need to up your production however, and start building cruisers, which are the slightly more expensive but much more powerful units. Finally, for late game play you will want to build dreadnoughts. These are the giant ships that can take on armies on their own, but still need support. The problem is there isn't much difference between units. Sure, some are quite unique. But let's take the default faction for example. They have a rocket frigate, rocket cruiser, and rocket dreadnought. The difference between the three? How many rockets they fire and how much damage they do. There are also air units, but all you really have are your fighters, bombers, and scouts.

All of this said, this game has great potential if it can have some balance updates, maybe some units added, and of course the matchmaking fixed. I highly recommend it for those looking for an RTS that is simple to get into but takes a lot of patience and practice to master.

reviewText:
Ashes of the Singularity is a RTS on a massive scale. You can build huge armies and conquer the mostly also huge maps.
It has some interesting new features compared to the usual genre representatives. For one theres the option to have your armies micro themselves. Which is pretty neat. The mechanic that provides and distributes ressources is pretty interesting as well, because the only way to get the ressources is through capturing points which will then produce ressources for you.
You can speed up the process by constructing extractors and other gathering enhancements. The need to control these points on the map add a new tactical element to the game. And the game requires some strategic thinking. Your `ground` forces move very slowly. Which means you should always know where they should be in the near future, so you have to think two or three steps ahead.
Lastly this game is mostly a multiplayer title. The campaign is really short, 11 missions, and can easily be played through.
Skirmishes against the AI are fun and on hard difficulties challenging, but will probably get boring after some time.
The graphics are okay to good. Huge battles do look pretty nice. But the map quality is rather disappointing. They mostly look the same and the same dosesn`t even look any good. No variety.
In the end theres to say : If you´re interested in RTS with tactical elements and a good AI you can risk a look.
I`d wait for a sale though. Because I cannont whole-heartedly recommend this game in its current state at the full price. 50% would be a pretty good deal.

reviewText: First let me just say that I enjoy this game, but that doesn't mean it doesn't have its problems. If you like RTS games I encourage you to try this game out for yourself because it in itself  is a good game but its nothing groundbreaking. Once you complete the campaign, which had its difficulty reduced for good reason, you will either have to play skirmish or online. The problem with skirmish is that the AI is unbalanced. Before you know it you will be attacked by the substrate factions favorite unit the punisher. This bomber is super over powered and will completely overwhelm your defenses before you're ready and even if you think you're ready. If there is enough (which there usually are) they can destroy your HQ in one pass equaling game over. this is my biggest pet peeve with the game and I'm sure/hope it will be fixed in the future. There is also a problem for me where the game will completely freeze once a match is over forcing me to completely sign off my computer for it to work again. Like I said earlier there really isn't anything groundbreaking from the game, but it is a pretty solid RTS that I find myself coming back to again and again so that is why I recommend it.

reviewText:
2000 units onscreen at once:  Game runs perfectly smooth on minimum system requirements.

2001 units onscreen at once:  Graphics card melts.


A++ will play again

---

A more serious review:

AotS is being compared with Planetary Annihilation and Supreme Commander.  It's a fair comparison - this game's mechanics are very well done, and allows MASSIVE wars between players.  The learning curve is easier than most other realtime strategies, but the single player campaign feels rushed like there wasn't enough time to finish it.

The resource system is intuitive, interesting, easy to use, and provides lots of strategic options while not requiring micromanagement.  In fact, not requiring micromanagement" seems to be the slogan of AotS
date: and units can be grouped into armies that are given commands as a group by clicking on any member of the army - very nice.\n\nThere are three resources: metal
recommended: radioactives and quanta.   Metal and radioactives work roughly like minerals and vespene gas from Starcraft
hoursPlayed:
but without (you guessed it) micromanagement.  Quanta is generated from buildings and used for orbital abilities (magic) plus upgrades.

The music is downright fantastic.

When zoomed in
voteText: the game doesn't look as good as Supreme Commander.  When zoomed out (ie: in actual gameplay) it looks better in many ways because you see the units
helpfulPercent: not the icons.\n\nOverall rating: Supreme Commander is one of the best RTS games ever made
votesHelpful: and I like playing AotS more.  The strategy
votesTotal: control system
votesFunny: resource management and music is just that good.  Highly recommended."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far so good. 2 hours of gameplay into the Beta and I already realise I don't want to play the game anymore!

But wait... not because it is rubbish, but because I think it is good. Don't want to ruin my experience of the full game when it comes out. I loved the C&C games in their time, but currently love Sup Com 1 and the expansion even more (Must add that I hated Sup Com 2. Mainly because of the lack of game speed control. It felt like it was designed to be a multiplayer game with single player added on as an after thought). This is the first game that has come close to the Sup Com experience. Still not quite as good i don't think, but I need to play the campaign once it is fully released to be sure.

Just wanted to say I really think it is going to be good. The only thing that will spoil it for me is if they focus on multiplayer. I dabble with mp in strategy games, but I really play them for the whole single player campaign experience... fingers crossed!

reviewText:
Ashes for the singularity is a great game. As someone who is really into the RTS genre, this game is perfect for me.
While I don't feel as if the two races are such a difference from eachother, (They don't feel like you're playing something entirely different) I do enjoy both of them.

I haven't encountered any slowdowns or bugs yet, which is something I am really happy with. Right now the steam overlay isn't working with directx12, which is something that the devs cannot do anything about. So I don't mind that.

I do believe this game is well optimized. When I am able to move more than a thousand units without any notice frame drop, I am sold. I love the zoom ins on the units. They are well detailed and well designed.

They also said on the website that if you buy it soon enough, you will get free extra dlc :) Everybody likes free extra dlc.

Do I recommend this game?

Yes.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is not total annihilation or supreme commander! It draws from those games yes, but they are doing their own thing and i like it alot.

I like the cap system where you establish supply routes and try to disrupt the enemy lines! Cut one of the lines and no matter how many mines they have on the other side they will get no money from them.

I like the eco where you have constant flow of resources in and out. You need to balance income vs spending since storage of resources is limited. This means if you mine more then you spend, those resources are lost! So if you gain resources you need to build more factories to spend it all.

The game is slow paced with more focus on planning and strategy. I love this. Dont get me wrong i like games like starcraft but i dont view sc as a strategy game. I view it as real time tactics game since it focuses on small battles where micro and clickspeed is key.
Slow paced does not mean no harass or skirmishing. Its really effective to send bombers behind enemy lines to bomb their resource points (really good if theyve not done a good job of providing aa. Really effective right after they capped the area since aa takes a little while to build)


Sound is bad. The units sound horrible when clicking on them!
Music is decent
Campaign: Havent played it
Only two factions but they both look really good.
Defence structures are to weak at the moment. Send in a few dreds with support and they melt instantly. Hopefully something will be added here down the line.
Cant have it to powerfull either as that would rend harassing pointless
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Not the greatest graphics, but great strategic depth and incredible scale. I regularly field armies of hundreds of units, and the maps are huge! Really enjoying my time with Ashes.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Ashes excels in scale, not only in the size of maps or numbers of units the game will run with, but depth of tactics avaliable.

Ashes encorages multitasking and grand strategic plan significantly more than micromanaging single battles. While some may find this difficult (handelling the overall war rather than commanding each unit in battle) the overall effect is that of a general commanding a global war, in contrast to the more standard RTS feel of a captain controlling a small force engaging in a skirmish.

Add to that the outstanding AI and wide variety of maps, along with a fledgling campain and online multiplayer and you have a game with real replay value.

While there are areas I would like to see the game grow, the ongoing support of the developers promises to meet most, if not all, of them.

I strongly recommend this game!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Let me open this review by stating that this game is NOT Supreme Commander (all iterations of it included). It might share some of it's looks and scale, but it is far from it. Before moving on with the review, it is good to keep an open mind that this game is different from any recent RTS'es that have come out. Different in a good way.

At first i thought it needed a couple of months more of development before an actual release. It felt a bit lacking in polish in some aspects that i would expect to see in a modern RTS title. Seeing however the speed and dedication the developers put into these constant updates post launch (upon this review we are at 1.1), i have to retract my initial thoughts and say that these guys know what they're doing.

Support them for they show the utmost dedication in the games that they release.

Diving into the game, i found that this is a great game. A great, well-balanced, solid RTS game that will NOT be for everyone. The NOT pertaining to those who do not like learning curves.

It may share similarities to many well known RTS's like Supreme Commander FA and Supreme Commander 2, but still manages to be its own game by introducing unique mechanics that feel fresh. Again, it may look like Supcom, but it plays very differently.

It's quite difficult to go into detail, because this is the first MACRO focused real-time strategy game out there in the wild. It focuses on the larger aspect of battles - aka wars - rather than micro managing units to win short skirmishes. Supreme commander is a big game too, however this game features units that behave according to their squad type, size, and overall composition. In this game, masses of units will move and fight accordingly in proper formation. When i say that armies go easily into the hundreds.

This is an important aspect of the game that can either be good or bad depending on your expectations. Not to mention that your mileage on these experiences will vary depending on your history of RTS's played. This game is no Supreme Commander FA, no Starcraft, no Company of Heroes. It is it's own - and by experience i can say that this game pulls it off well.

One of the best things about this game that is worth admiration is the development team behind it.

As I've mentioned above, they provide CONSTANT updates and TRANSPARENCY on the path the game will be taking in the coming weeks and even as far as months go. The developers show that they have the best intentions for the customers and as such they are active in the forums. That alone earns Three thumbs Up" in my book. (I had to grow another thumb
date: lol)\n\nWhy does this deserve such praise? Simple. Many RTS's and even the newer batches
hoursPlayed:
Deserts of Kharak!) seem to run away with your hard earned money and purposely ignore the requests on their forums.

Another thing that makes this game awesome? The AI. That glorious AI.

So
voteText: what about it? It's brilliant
helpfulPercent: in the literal and figurative sense. It works magnificently and will adapt well with whatever you throw at it. You will get pummeled at NORMAL difficulty at first... or forever depending on how good you are at adapting your strategies. That is a pleasure no other modern RTS's can even hope of coming close to.\n\nIn summary
votesHelpful: for anyone looking for a challenge
votesTotal: for massive wars
votesFunny: and a fresh approach to the lacking RTS genere
commentsCount: this game is the perfect package for you.\n\nAgain
column16: a word of warning; you will lose against a NORMAL AI that doesn't cheat. It is by far the best AI i have ever seen in a strategy game (Much better than the Sorian AI). So come - and be baptized! ;)"

reviewText: Very large maps and incredible unit counts.  I'm sure there is a cap but I've yet to see any sign of one. reviewText:
As someone who has put well over three thousand hours into Supreme Commander and Forged Alliance but was very disappointed by SupCom 2 and Planetary Annihilation, I was tepid Ashes of Singularity. On the whole, it is a good game. It does have its flaws, most notably unit speed, even the light units, is pretty slow which means expect a fair amount of time to be spent waiting for armies to get in position. The only other major flaw I see is a lack of tactical options other than overwhelming brute force to win.

The linked resource system is an interesting developement which eliminates turtling as you must expand as well as cut your opponents supply links to starve them. So expect a lot of skirmishes around link nodes! This includes forward bases, if a forward base's link is severed, it goes offline.

Overall, an interesting DX12 showcase game that I hope continues to be updated and polished, I average ~30fps in 1080p, a bit lower in clashes, with an i6 6500k, GTX 970 and 16g ram at maximum settings.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Outstanding RTS for it being in Alpha stages. Having played RTS's for years, it's easy to see a game that is loaded with potential. The graphics and UI are incredible. The detail already in place on terran, units, buildings, etc. are great and will likely go much farther upon release. WIth the sheer scale one can play a game on (hundreds, even thousands of units), it could get confusing for people new to an RTS. For me, it makes the game very enjoyable. What bettter way to unwind after a long days work than to whipe out the enemy with a dozen Dreadnaughts, 25 artillery cruisers, 25 heavy cruisers, and swarms of frigates. Oh, and I almost forgot about the bombers that are so devistating, you better keep your units away from groud zero.

The game, obviously, has a lot more to be added; more indepth storyline, campaign mode, more factions, more units, more perks, etc. But so far, the developers are really on to something big. With the right creativity and time to impliment and test, I would be very surprised if this game doesnt win strategy of the year or more.

On a side note, I have yet to experience a crash, or any serious glitch for that matter; at least not that I could notice. My rig has an GTX 970 4GB, i7-5820K Haswell lga 2011 x99 chip and overlocked, 16GB of DDR4 RAM and 500GB SSD. Game runs like a dream but if I see a glitch or crash, I'll let the dev team know, as I hope everyone else is.

Can't wait for the finished product!!!

reviewText:
I enjoyed it.  The campaign is ok, I will say it's mostly there just to be there but it's got some humor built in.  I actually got the founders pack for this because I love huge scale RTS games.

The graphics are good, and it runs well all things considered.  There are some nvidia driver issues as nvidia is getting their ♥♥♥ kicked in DX12.  It seems like DX12 doesnt react well with overlays so most stability issues can be traced to that.

The soundtrack and audio are all on point.

The biggest flaw is the lack of depth.  I think that'll be improved over time as the developers seem committed to it.  They've released games in the past that feel unfinished but always own up and update them soon after.  This one was a good release, but It could use some more unit diversity.

I would highly recommend because there isn't another modern game like it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Brilliant. Absolutely brilliant.

A strategy game of massive scale that is not overwhelming. How awesome is that?

This game excels at having the player control large armies composed of the units of their choosing. For example, one game I had a the Cronus siege dreadnought (similar to a capitol ship in Sins of a Solar Empire) surrounded by escorting fighter squadrons and defensive units. I parked it in firing range of the enemy base and let it pound away.

If you enjoy games such as Supreme Commander and Sins of a Solar Empire, I can not recommend this game enough.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even though this game is in early access it has less bugs than most games released in to production these days.

What makes this RTS great in my opinion:

Its simplistic where it needs to be but there is a lot of depth.  Example.  Think of this game in the realm of supcom, but you do not need a huge sprawling base.  instead you build forward bases, and your heavy units can be upgraded the more experience they get.  The upgrades are done tastefully and there isnt a mega tree you need to micromanage.  Don't get me wrong, to be good at this game is not easy - it has a lot of depth, but its not overwhelming either.  Maps vary in size from very big - think supcom - to smaller.  MP games can take a while - not a really fast paced RTS.  If you are looking for the next CnC or Star Craft... this probably isnt it.  But if you are looking for something with some tactical depth then this is probably the game you've been looking for.

The devs support the game with real content.  It seems like they'll have a major update then a couple patch updates.  When they get the things ironed out they bring in more content. Normally I don't typically recommend early access but this game is truly deserving.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

YES! Just bought this today after umming and aaring over buying into early access but i must say even know this is a beta currently i am impressed with the game. I was a little hesitant at first buying this as i had been burnt by Planetary Annihilation and the fact im running an Amd 280x which isnt exactly cutting edge anymore but even on low with a mixture of medium setting im getting 40+ fps with dips to 30 in largish battles. Being a beta there are things that can be tweaked, like the UI I feel could use a little more information when you are selected on armies like how many units with what capabilities are in it and how many armies are selected in the control group you have set. Also a quicker way to find your dreadnaught in a massive control group. Now this all could be there already but if it is it needs to be made clearer i feel. Overall i feel there could be more information in general.

I myself am not to concerned about the performance currently as im guessing Oxide will optimise it furthur in the coming month for release and the fact that i am running a I7 4790K with 16gb of ram and upgrading to a Pascal or Polaris series GPU in June/July. I know not everyone can have a cutting edge gpu but even on low to mid settings the game is still damn pretty.

Buy this game if you are a fan of Total Annihilation and Supreme Commander FA. This is now along with them one of my favorite RTS games of all time.
