reviewText:
I'll be honest here, AotS is more of a showcase of current/next-gen technology rather than an actual RTS game.

Selling point of this game is how the devs revolutionize game engine, AI development and computer technology as a whole. The game supports multicore processing, pairing of gfx cards to share load(you don't need xfire/SLI and it is cross platform compatible, i.e AMD with Nvidia), building the game around dx12 with all of its glory and misery, with gorgeous and detailed graphics, not forgetting also smart AI that does the unit micro'ing for the player by assigning groups/squads as well as challenging AI bots as opponents. Notice that the game is all about showcasing technology.

What the game lacks is actual gameplay. It is for the most part lacking and barren in terms of strategy & tactics, unit composition & pool, game depth, modding, factions count, unit tiers & tech trees, even the scale of the game is disappointing for a grand RTS. Yes, all these aspects are mediocrely done. Well its nice that the game has AI micro'ing but it is at best very amatuerish. Half the time i wish i could personally micro and macro. The economy balancing gameplay is also non existent, it copies Sup Com but its too simplified and dumbed down so much so that theres nothing to manage. Honestly, the AI technology behind the game is too good that i always end up having nothing to do in game, everything is on auto mode and managed by the AI. The entire AI, core game and structure that the devs developed end up constricting and boxing up the gameplay.

Seriously, the gameplay is a disappointment overall, is this game supposed to be a movie, a interactive click and play adventure? Devs boast of trying to meld Sup Com with Starcraft and Dawn of War or Ground Control but what we get is pretty much an extremely weak RTS game that suffers from identity crisis and shallow RTS elements, theres no depth in the gameplay. What it has is merely beautiful eye candy and the awesome technology fueling it. So what? The essence of gaming is the gameplay itself. AotS is beautiful, but plain. There’s nothing here that hasn’t been done before and done better. And it doesnt have the spark or x-factor that made other RTS games like Sup Com, Warcraft/Starcraft, Dawn of War, Ground Control so engaging and lasting.

This game is perfect as a tech demo/showcase for computer engineers, tech geeks etc who want to learn and pioneer the future of gaming. If you're looking for a comprehensive and deep RTS, you can't find it here... at least not yet. Maybe when the expansions and dlcs come pouring in it'll turn more into a proper game rather than a tech showcase. I applaud the devs for trying to push gaming technology forward but AotS, is definitely not a full-fledged game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is pretty god damn amazing.

So far incredabliy smooth performance for me on a subjective experience level with no notable bugs or CTDs.

I note this mostly because and back me up on this people its EA, so GJ devs.

The gameplay is a blast so far. I love the map scale and detail of the unit interactions. The ability global ability access through units as well as upgrades is intuitive and slick.

The unit managment with armys and assiging groups has impressed me a great deal. I was concerned that with a game of this scale would have some serious unit micro managment issues. But I could not have been more wrong. It works like a dream. The army system does a fantastic job of allowing you to quickly segregate units and reform them into a new army as well as reinforce armys without a second thougt from your nearest production base.


The sense of scale I feel needs a mention. The command of the massive dreadnaughts is awesome. Watching them duke it out on the field has been great fun. And the maps are geniunly massive I can only hope for more as time goes on and I have little doubt we will see exactly that based on the updates so far.

I feel like its a fantastic outgrowth of TA/surpreme commander style lineup of games ( supcom1 not 2).

Combat is also very intense. The units are nicely varried and make for a hell of a show. You will however probably need a decent machine if not an outright beast to max this thing out. Because I am running a decent system and the unit cap... well i have not really found one yet idk how high it goes but damn its high. Prepare yourself for the mayhem.

And the orbital powers will add plently of that as well between strikes scans and abiltiy to heal they add a nice strategic depth to the game as well as the ability to be blocked by ground structures and force deep strikes to take them out.

So get ready to unleash some dreadnaughts because Ashes of Singularity will suck you in if your a fan of the large scale  RTS games like Total Annhilation or Supreme Commander. If by chance you are more skeptical I highly recommend giving it a shot on sale as unlike supreme commander or TA the level of micro is significantly reduced and allows a great deal more focus on the essence of your strategy and the combat and I feel that would also have a broader appeal to the wider RTS community of players while also still keeping fundementals of the startegic base building alive from the previous spritutal incarnations of this RTS subgenre.

* some features are not in and thus I have not commented on them. I will update for features like acendacy war once they are implimented.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is pretty god damn amazing.

So far incredabliy smooth performance for me on a subjective experience level with no notable bugs or CTDs.

I note this mostly because and back me up on this people its EA, so GJ devs.

The gameplay is a blast so far. I love the map scale and detail of the unit interactions. The ability global ability access through units as well as upgrades is intuitive and slick.

The unit managment with armys and assiging groups has impressed me a great deal. I was concerned that with a game of this scale would have some serious unit micro managment issues. But I could not have been more wrong. It works like a dream. The army system does a fantastic job of allowing you to quickly segregate units and reform them into a new army as well as reinforce armys without a second thougt from your nearest production base.


The sense of scale I feel needs a mention. The command of the massive dreadnaughts is awesome. Watching them duke it out on the field has been great fun. And the maps are geniunly massive I can only hope for more as time goes on and I have little doubt we will see exactly that based on the updates so far.

I feel like its a fantastic outgrowth of TA/surpreme commander style lineup of games ( supcom1 not 2).

Combat is also very intense. The units are nicely varried and make for a hell of a show. You will however probably need a decent machine if not an outright beast to max this thing out. Because I am running a decent system and the unit cap... well i have not really found one yet idk how high it goes but damn its high. Prepare yourself for the mayhem.

And the orbital powers will add plently of that as well between strikes scans and abiltiy to heal they add a nice strategic depth to the game as well as the ability to be blocked by ground structures and force deep strikes to take them out.

So get ready to unleash some dreadnaughts because Ashes of Singularity will suck you in if your a fan of the large scale  RTS games like Total Annhilation or Supreme Commander. If by chance you are more skeptical I highly recommend giving it a shot on sale as unlike supreme commander or TA the level of micro is significantly reduced and allows a great deal more focus on the essence of your strategy and the combat and I feel that would also have a broader appeal to the wider RTS community of players while also still keeping fundementals of the startegic base building alive from the previous spritutal incarnations of this RTS subgenre.

* some features are not in and thus I have not commented on them. I will update for features like acendacy war once they are implimented.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Regardless of being Early Access, AotS is a very well rounded RTS, the learning curve is epic at the moment as there is no tutorial however a quick youtube and google and you will have the basics.

Overall this game is like nothing ive ever played, i love RTS games and tend to purchase new ones with resonable reviews however this is the first Beta RTS ive invested in and i cannot be disapointed.

perforamnce is heavy those recommended specs are acurate my rig is struggaling with just 8gb of ram, that said once it goes into release 1.0 im sure this will be ironed out.


if you like RTS, if you like MASSIVE armies (3000 units plus easy) if you like a challenge (AI uses every thread on your CPU to best think how to kick your bottom) then buy it, even if you dont just buy it anyway its honestly brilliant.


* no mention of graphics etc in here as the game is still in beta its just left alpha this month, the terrain isnt pretty its basic textures but the ships and units are all well textured and the terrain update is due in the next week or so i understand.



/Edit - Native support for UltraWidescreen - this is a MAJOR bonus for anyone rocking a eyefinity or ultrawide setup no other RTS seems to work properly AotS just does :)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI really like the concept. Being a fan of both Sins of a Solar Empire made by the same developer, and the cult classic Supreme Commander, this game breathes new life into the RTS genre. It is a little buggy, and my biggest complaint is not being able to zoom all the way out, even if that means only seeing icons instead of the beautifully modeled units themselves. The game seems a bit too demanding for what it is, but I understand that it's because it uses part of your GPU to manage the AI. Which, I suppose, is innovative. I would definitely reccomed this game to anyone who liked Supreme Commander, or any other RTS game of the like.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was worried given the reviews other people made. I always read the negative ones, and none of the positive ones, to get an idea of what's wrong.

But I actually bought it anyway, and really enjoyed it. I will agree with most of the others that it needs some work, polishing, and tweaks. And the AI isn't as advanced as they claim.
It's really fun though. If you are looking for a fresh RTS, you get that here. If you are looking for something ground breaking that changes the genre, well we haven't seen anything like that in a decade - it's just an RTS like all the rest

The unit cap being super massive is a heck of a nice twist , where SupCom and Total Annihilation are the only real contenders. And I think it's fair to say we've all burned those titles in hours played.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Soooo: Ashes. Right. Well can't say I don't love it, and have to be a bit lenient for the Early Access, just hoping it's in VERY Early Access. here's Why:

Pros
- Good Graphics
- Easy to learn
- Good maps
- Unique twist on the resource system
- Simple upgrade system
- Victory Point System

Cons
- Perhaps too many different resources
- Only one faction (Early Access)
- Bad ratio of S:M:L maps (Yeah just being picky)
- Laggy (Early Access)
- Why are 'increase storage' and 'increase all unit damage/health' using the same resource???

But yes, plenty of potential, possibly the New Supreme Commander if it pulls through. Looking forward to the full release.

reviewText:
AOTS is a new strategy game from the creators of the best space themed RTS in existence Sin of a solar empire.

I haven't played the single player campaign yet so cannot comment on the quality there, though I have heard good things.

Multiplayer skirmishes are where it is at for me. I have really enjoyed getting to know the two playable teams (with a third coming in the future) and found the A.I to be a great challenge. They will punish you for leaving small gaps in your defence (no anti-air, weak units left unattended). The best battles happen when there is a deadlock for control of the central point which provides a resource required to win. There can be some epic back and forth moments where the scores swing wildly as team counter attack, this is when Ashes really shines for me.

Another thing worth mentioning is the ability to reinforce an army on the fly. Now that I have the feature I can't believe RTS games didn't have this in the past! Pressing ctrl+Number assigns armies to that number. Once an army is selected you can build any units available and they will automatically head to reinforce the army directly. I LOVE THIS!

Give it a try. Dev's are working hard on updates but it is a really enjoyable game as it stands!

All in all, this is my new RTS and I feel could be a great RTS like the C&C/Red Alert games. Plus this games AI is crazy when set to Painful"."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far so good, I'm playing on pretty much minimal settings and it looks pretty decent, the games AI grows quite nicely as you increase it's difficulty. It really does feel like Supcom meets COH with the way claiming regions of the map to gain resources works.

I feel like there needs to be more variety of units/buildings before the full release some form of stealth or subterranean units would be really nice! I can't help but think looking towards Total Annihilation and even some the C&C Tiberean Wars series could represent some interesting ideas towards giving the units some more interesting mechanics.

A further thought, I think the lack of variety is really that I feel more support based units/buildings would be a nice change as at the moment it very much feels like having more firepower/damage absorbtion results in a win.

Ultimately it is already a decent game, still doesn't feel as inspiring as WC3, Cossacks or Total Annihilation. I'm really looking forwards to see where this game is come release day and hope they don't add minor unpates with a couple of extra units and a bundle of maps like many games have done in the genre in the past.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wow, this is a fun game, even though it's only in beta.  I like good RTS games that aren't about rushing, but instead about strategy, and this seems to deliver.  I know I've only played 5 hours, but I'm already very impressed.

What's good:
Great visuals, especially ship detail and such.
Line of sight fog of war.
Resource gathering--feels like Rise of Nations, which I like.
Unit control is simple.
BIG armies.

What could use work:
Too few types of strategic resources.  There's basically 3, but only two on the map, the other is from a building you build.
Building/tech tree is too shallow, so your research upgrades don't impact where you go.  It does end up being about who can field the largest army in the right spot.
Requires the latest and greatest video cards.  My year old laptop is the only computer that can play it in my house. :(

Overall, very happy with the game, and it'll drive me to buy new computers, just so I can play this with my kids.  I look forward to seeing how it progresses in the future.

Edit:

After 5 more hours, the game is feeling a bit shallow.  We'll see if the trend continues.

reviewText:
Pros:
Unprecedented Scale
Solid Foundation / Basic Mechanics
Excellent AI

Cons
Bland Art and Units
Sloppy Campaign
Underwhelming UI
Price

The big nitpick is just the pricepoint. much of the negatives can be attributed merely to a relatively limited budget forcing a limited but solid base experience. If sold for a lower price, maybe that context would grant some understanding and make the state of the game better match expectations. It's too high for what it is.

The saving grace is the future readiness of the game. Ashes scales great with improving hardware and with continued support by the developer the game is constantly improving. And at the end of the day, value worth is relative, but the game is still fun.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Now AotS is released I will review again. I was optimistic and pleased with the Early access, I wrote about and had hoped for more...primarily I was seeking further balance, hoping for further units, buildings and factions.

The visuals are very good and the game has run really smoothly but I still cant help but feel let down. The promise of massive scale and sheer numbers of units has been met but only well sort of.

IMO the design and balance of the game, making it a fight over resources and VP's, completely dictates the flow of play rather than letting it occour naturally. It feels forced. Most RTS games become a fight for resource or VP's/territory anyway why force it? I wrote before about how different play styles are unrewarded compared to an early aggresive expansionist style and this still rings true.
I am still dissapointed by the buildings, units and factions. Buildings and units in real terms are limited. The Meta Unit / Army is a good idea but it quickly leads to stronger generic combinations and you then only have a few unit" options and or combinations which are stronger and worth investing in. This is way short of most RTS games. The buldings
date: 3 factory types and 1 air factory hardly ground breaking.\n\nOrbitals are good
recommended:
like the idea and its executed and balanced well.

Only 2 factions. They are balanced against eachother well so its not blindingly obvious which is stronger which is plus but again I wanted more.

BUT - I have still been enjoying it. I am happy to admit my play style is more towards turtle/researcher than expansionist which doesn't quite fit the AotS mould and this is part of my issue. I cannot play how I would normally
hoursPlayed:
I cannot decide for myself which strategy to use as it doesnt really work with how the game is designed. As such I believe it doesnt quite deliver on the promise.

My Longest match ( vs AI to test scale ) was over 4 hours and unit cap didnt come into it. It was pretty irrelevant after 1 hr or so with it being large enough ( with enough constant fighting for territory ) to make the game enjoyable. Its like the design of the game actually doesnt play on its USP of massive scale and unit numbers which is just odd.

And this is my over riding feeling of the game so far. It looks good
voteText: sounds good
helpfulPercent: its enjoyable and has many positives but its not calling me back time after time to keep playing. I wish there was neautral rather than yes/no.\n\nIt depends what sort of game you are looking for. I would still recommend it as worth trying as I know plenty of RTS gamers will like it. For me it misses the mark a bit."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is some what of a tough one but I can not really recommend this game But I cant really put it down either.. The easiest comparison to this came would be supreme commander.

But supreme commander had three factions that had a unique look and tons of units. Where Ashes just has you level up you armor and weapons, that upgrade in SCFA is an actually new unit. On top of that there were naval options, there were options to set up transport ferry system so your units would rally in one area where a series of drop ships would then pick them up and drop them off automaticly. There were also tons of base defense options. Ashes has a very limited base defense.

While saying that, I have been finding myself enjoying this, especialy after I realized that in SC the tier 3 units were nice buy you kind of never touched the other ones again. And there is a certain fun to watching all your missliems and lazers just decimate the other tem. The upgrades for the Dreads is nice  and I do like watching the fights. Wish the wrecks would stick around. Stardock does have a good rep for upgrades and trying to add to there game so huge potential here. I wish there wasa review option between negaive and positive.

But if you LIked SC and SoaSE then I would recomend purchasing this. . But Only because I have faith in Stardock.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not recommending nor dis-recommending the game.
Bought it for the DX12 benchmark.

After playing a few rounds... Here's who this game is for:
- You like RTS games in general.
- You like cool graphics and great sound in your games.
- You are excited to play an RTS with large scale.
- You like RTS games with a bit faster pace than say SupCom FA.

Who this game is NOT for:
- You're a die hard SupCom fan.
- You really like games that can take a long time.
- You like a lot of diversity in your units.

In the end, wait for a steam sale, and buy the game.  It's probably worth Steam sale prices.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very Promising and deep RTS experience, have sunk a few hours in now and can tell you this is a pretty well thought out go at an RTS with a lo of lessons learned from the past and some refreshing ideas about how not to have some annoying ♥♥♥♥ build an impregnable fortress and artillerise every poor sod on the map without prejudice!

i love the unit design and naval feel of the uints, and the battlegroups mechanic is pretty sweet and takes alot of the micromanagement of individual armies out of the mix, and trust me you will need it, the AI is quite scary even at relatively low levels and there is a real sting in the tail if you let your guard or attention slip for a minute and focus on one area of the map for too long before realising your other areas are abou to get ♥♥♥♥ed!

to summarise i am very happy with what i am seeing and the 0.7 update has added some very nice features, there is a lot of potential for some very fun MP times ahead with this game!

Thanks for Reading, Desk out

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game visuals are very nice.

The DirectX 12 will not work for in-home steaming yet; you have to use DX11.

Controls have some quirks, unit selection can get muddled, when to attack and when to move, it doesn't always do what is expected.

Game crashes less, since the last version.

On a personal note on the AI as it currently sits.
I'm not a new to RTS I have been at it since Dune, and I'm about average in skill level (It was never a goal for me to be the best at it), with that in mind, I have not won one game against the AI in this on EASY level.
There are 8 levels, the only lower setting is beginner, which in essence shuts off the AI, so they don't fight back.
With it on easy, if you attack one of the bases of the AI be prepared for a non stop onslaught, with multiple dreadnaughts attacking you (when you have only had time to build 1).  It seems the AI is a little ramped up as it sits right now.
During the fighting while your trying to survive, the AI is still building more, and still playing the capture game as well.  I have not tried to play the game at a higher level, as it is frustrating enough on easy.
Its not the AI is smart and out doing me on strategy on easy, its just that it can do 10x more than me, it knows the status of all units and what they are doing, and commands them all at the same time, unlike a human player that has to focus on one thing at a time even only for 1 or 2 seconds, the difference between 1 second and 100 milliseconds is massive, and puts the player at a massive disadvantage.

I sure there will be tuning of the AI in the future, why else is there 8 levels to it.

For multiplayer, its a blast.
Yep not much to say about Multiplayer, accept that is the reason to get the game now, its a lot of fun.  If you want a single player experience, wait for the release or at least until they put in the campaigns.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're like me, and you like to turtle into a base or two and make it damn near impenetrable in most RTS games, then you're going to be out of your comfort zone.

That's not a bad thing. At least, it's not for me. I've been wanting to learn more aggressive tactics and playstyles, but haven't ever been forced to. In most RTS games I play, I can turtle, build up a huge army, and then go out and essentially conquer them without much problem. Not in this one.

You can make a base damn near impenetrable, but only as the game gets going, and only if you did a bit of exploration before.

There is a huge problem with being a turtle right from the start in this game. Most bases have two or three Metal deposits, but no Radioactive deposits. You need radioactive for advanced units, so that presents a major problem to winning if you just turtle it up right away.

So the early game essentially forces exploration for the sake of advancement and victory.

It's also not a match about wiping out the enemy" but rather "holding strategic points until you get enough victory points to win." This also forces expansion
hoursPlayed: and aggressive tactics.\n\nI'm glad. This is the type of game that seems to both punish and reward exploration

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a good game. They say they draw inspiration from games like TA and SC, which was really exciting for me to hear. Personally I don't see any semblance between them, but I am still finding AotS to be very enjoyable. It's fast paced and very macro heavy. You need to quickly manage a lot of different aspects of your war in order to really excell against your opponents.

Downsides so far are:
-The occasional low memory crash (I have 16gb that barely goes above 50% utilization in game) when playing in dx12,
-Difficult to quickly determine whether a resource node has a harvesting structure built on it,
-Difficult to quickly determine composition of a group, and other misc UI short comings that devs are aware of and working to fix.

Other then that, great game in it's current state, very stable in dx11 and mostly stable in dx 12. I'm very excited to see what this game turns into in the coming months of development. :)

reviewText:
This game is officially out, but it still feels unfinished. They spent all that time polishing the engine, but everything else was abandoned half-way. You can’t rebind the controls. There is absolutely no voice overs in game for the campaign, which by the way is only “Episode 1”.  Mechanics are strewn about still needing work.

For example, the Army system is a very good idea, but is completely unwieldy. Try assigning multiple dreadnoughts to an army and the thing falls apart. Form an army out of a long stream of units and the ones that are about to take the objective will retreat to some centre of gravity. Still haven’t figure out a good way to detach just a few units.

The mini-map shows an utter contempt for your desire to have situational awareness. Is that coloured blob territory held? A swarm of factory units? A colossal rush of dreadnought?  No idea! Now in Supreme Commander you could just tactical zoom and look at the icons, but if that’s a feature it’s never been explained.

The audio is completely unhelpful. It says Enemy Dreadnought Sighted"

recommended: no clue which one is taking fire. "Dreadnought taking critical damage"

Selecting and ordering units just gives an annoying electronic sound that doesn't lend any kind of personality to the units.\n\nThe campaign is just "Episode 1". All the missions that aren’t tutorials are basically just a skirmish with some wonky starting conditions. The plot basically starts from nowhere and goes nowhere. None of the character have anything approaching personality

reviewText:
I can honestly say that Ashes has a way to go. I really want to like this game, but it just isn’t there yet!!

I own a lot of RTS games including Ashes, Planetary Annihilation, “Titans”, SC and some other titles and PA for me is at this stage much better. I completed the single player of ashes and I was a bit disappointed for a game that was hyped this much. As Brendan mentioned some of the missions you replay and reload saved games and AutoSaves until you are blue. Just a note, sometimes its better just to restart the hole mission!!

The enemy Dreadnoughts are insanely strong, if you don’t have a Dreadnought of your own you better hope you have an army size of 200+ and a lot of Dreadnought killers and even with this army you will be able to destroy your enemy at the cost of your hole army!! But don’t think your Dreadnoughts are anything as strong as the enemy, they will be wiped out by the most mediocre of armies.

Towers are useless, once again unbalanced as the enemy’s towers can last quite a while if you attack them but your defences are mere bugs they need to wipe from the windshield on their way to kill you.

You will never have enough resources not even if you own each node on the map. The only time you will have full resources is when you have reached your army cap and nothing builds anymore.

The thing that bugged me the most was when I create an army or join forces to an existing army the AI goes totally insane. Your units start moving around probably to join up with the slowest strongest unit but if you ordered your army to attack a certain enemy you will see your army turning around and running from the battle. Also in this state your units refuse to obey your commands even if you position the army right next to where the bulk of the units are.
I do like the graphics of the game and I do believe with some major improvements the game can become enjoyable to the point of SC, PA Titans … At this stage I will not advise anybody to buy this game above SC or PA Titans.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I used to have the handle of DI_Reaper in supreme commander before some noob decided to take my name.

I have dedicated a large portion of my younger years to learning strategy.  From formation strategy, economical warfare based on geographics, choke points, infantry tactics, and basic gaming formulas for optimum building orders.
I originally posted a question in the forum for this game detailing 7 major fundamentals that each real time strategy game requires to impliment the different aspects of actual war into the game.

With one race of the game, I see the basic econimic strucutre and unit utility expressing a potential to match Supreme Commander Vanilla.  DO NOT expect something more superb than Supreme Commander FA, which took 6 years of development and updates.  EXPECT this game to get to that point.

The strategist behind this game in how to launch his alpha stage, with limited consumer options and overall balance within these options available demonstrates this teams capability.



As one of the top 4v4 tournament players in supreme commander FA, red alert 2, and tiberium sun, I feel confident in my opinion that this game is worthy of getting your hopes up.
-Me

Business suggestion: If this game does not fund the next 2 dlcs, kickstart the next 3 with a graphics overhaul for direct x 13 whenever it comes out.
Take care of us, we take care of you.
-The community

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Really promising game, and while it's clear its early access this feels like what early access should be. The core of the game is clearly well developed, the graphics are solid and it already performs well in 4k with everything turned up on my dual R9 350 card, though the benchmark confirmed I'm GPU bound 100% of the time still!

The biggest thing I like after just a couple matches is the slower pace at which the early and mid game unfold, and the way smart use of terrain, vision and army comp are heavily rewarded compared to pumping out units fast in a starcraft style timing attack.

I do feel like each starting base should have a more defensible first radioactives deposit, but otherwise the maps feel like they're in good shape. Until the second faction is in balance will be very hard to judge, but it seemed like every unit was desirable to build at some point.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Since this is an Early Access review - I'll just say that the developers have done an accurate job (I feel) of stating exactly what to expect and where the game is in development. Pretty spot on regarding the current abilities of the build. That said, it is equally spot-on in terms of its source material, and this does feel like a soon-to-be bigger and better version of games we've played in the past.

Since I've played TA, Sins, PA, supcom, starcraft, etc, I felt right at home, so maybe here's hoping they put their own twist or spin on it as it goes forward. They certainly brought something familiar and fresh with Sins, so I hope they can do it again with a SupCom clone.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll wait to play further until multiGPU support comes along, but the game is ok in its current state. Here are some notes:
*Command issuing is a little bit unresponsive.
*This is hopefully a bug, but audio seems like it came from flash in 2005. It's weird because the audio files are really high quality and the benchmark showed reasonable audio. Maybe because of DX11.
*Windows 10 increses preformance no doubt (AMD).
*Bugs are there, but it's early access so it's almost to be expected.
*Crashes are to be expected at it's current state.

Has a great potential overall but would not reccomend the 40€ (or your regional equivelent) pricetag while it's in early access.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe game states it's a pre-beta build so it's got that little bit of clunkiness and stutter from time to time but that will be easily sorted with some more optimisation updates. The game itself is absolutley amazing!!! I cannot state that enough, because for something to be this amazing in such an early stage is a breath of fresh air from all this crap that gets released these days. If you enjoy any type of RTS game or supreme commander then this game is definatley for you as it smashs the bar set by most futuristic setting RTS's. The gameplay is a slower pace compared to games like supreme commander but the units more than make up for this in numbers and sheer power, which makes battles extremely good to watch and command. With constant updates from the developers this game will be a main stay among RTS fans for many years to come.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A good start, but the unit controls are far too clunky.
The game has a lot of potential but right now the game makes it far too challenging to rally, group, and control your units in an efficient manner.   Your units will often be sitting at base ungrouped, units going backwards/impossible to control, and random crashes.

TLDR, wait until the game is released to consider buying it.

reviewText:
I have to change my review and my recommendation. Simple becaue the GAME CHEATS so bad on the final campaign scenario, End Game.

When I have 8 or 9 dreadnoughts up against a single ravager and they are pounding it with damage and it is not taking any at all and I for some reason am not able to use any of my global abilities, I say the game is cheating. All of my dreadnoughts started out with more health than that single ravager. I had forgotten about my quanta and increased my health, damage, and range  like 6 levels, when I looked at the ravager it's health also increased, in fact it more than doubled!

There is more that I noticed while playing the game but there are to many things to recount about how I noticed the game cheating, yes it is that bad.

I enjoy playing single player games and I look forward to the single player campaign in games like this. Unfortunately the single player campaign really looses out. The story line is meh and the story boards that keep popping up during the game get really annoying especially  when you have to click off of them to continue playing. They should at least make it so you can continue to play and control your units during the story pop ups.

Because of all the above I have to change my recommendation to not recommended at least for the single player games.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game. I was a huge fan of the TA series and to a lesser extent the Supreme Commander series. This seemed like it was poised to become the next great army level" RTS. Once I started playing it however I discovered that the content is extremely shallow. There is effectively only 1 faction that has been fleshed out and that faction has such a limited choice of units that the strategy is fairly limiting.

The concept of being able to form "army groups" and being able to manipulate at a macro scale is a really nifty mechanic and idea. For those of us who aren't big into micro management that makes the game var more pleasent to play.The problem is that there just isn't enough variety to really make it fun.

I really wish I'd not purchased this in early access. I'd hoped that by the time they went live they'd really haf fleshed out both factions

reviewText:
As one commenter so kindly puty it - read up on this game before you buy. This is a 'buy if you want to support the devs' situation - you are not getting anywhere near £40's worth of game at this point.

That said, I still cant recomend this game (putting the price asside).

Key reasons I cant recomend:

- Limited Unit tree. 18~ units per side including builders is a poor show in my opinion (I read someone comparing this to supcom, dont make me laugh). Even after reading up, I found nothing on expanding the unit trees.
- Zoom out has a stupidly low ceiling height for a game which says 'Fight across planets'. It has been confirmed that this won't change either (by a dev on the forums). They feel like they dont want to 'rip off' Supreme Commander's tactical zoom - a choice which is in my opinion a total error. The current zoom ceiling they have is awful.
- Unit AI is IDIOTIC (units will sit around doing nothing as another unit quite literally next to them is destroyed by an enemy army). This is true as of 02/02/2016 - hopefully this will improve.
- Unit deaths/explosions are dissapointingly ugly.


All of the above said, this game is way more fun than I origionaly gave it credit for. If they fix the unit diversity (Ideally add another playable faction as well as expanding the current ones) and give more options for resource exploitation this could be a recomend.

EDIT for release:

The game has changed very little since my previous review, despite now being 'released'. What a shame this is such an underbaked project propped up by the adoration of those willing to accept less (or perhaps I'm much too critical for the poor quality of games which seem to be the norm now).

If you read things about this game and were pulled in by references to Sup Com; DO NOT BUY. You will be massivley dissapointed. What made Sup Com great is not in this game.

reviewText:
I unfortunately had to refund this game.

Apparently my resolution, 1600x1200, is not supported properly in this game. 1920x1080 is recommended, but even when I change the resolution to 1600x900 (to match the aspect ratio), the text is still completely unreadable and the UI scaling is locked to 80%, making everything tiny. The game only properly letterboxed itself when I minimized and maximized the game again (but I still couldn't read the text). No matter what resolution I choose, the game is unplayable for me.

If you want to play this game, make sure you have a monitor that can display 1920x1080, or don't waste your time.

reviewText:
If you came here for a grand strategy game similar to Supreme Commander then prepare to be disappointed. This game is lacking in areas that even SupCom had done correctly. Though SupCom was’t perfect, it at least had focus firing, individual unit controls, and allowed you to dived grouped units and spilt them into new groups. This game does not. It has so much going for it, but honestly it's lacking in some of the most basic elements that made these grand strategy games so easy to play.

Want to kill that single pesky cruiser before it does any more damage? Nope, can’t focus fire.

Want to move your units to another position? Watch them ever so slowly move then die since you can’t angle and position them correctly.

Want to split off a group from your main army? Can’t do that without reforming your whole army and having all your units scatter!

Units are hard to control, unit AI isn't very good, lack of focus fire for attacking, lack of splitting armies" (their version of groups with its own problem)
date: lack of hot keys to select units types
recommended:
and overly sluggish unit movement. I have not enjoyed this game and I am disappointed that I have to wait for patches to (maybe) fix these problems and a plethora of bugs. Such is modern gaming development. Shove it out of the door and fix it later.

At this point I do not suggest buying this game. Maybe in the future it will be worth it but right now save your money.

Update: A comment to the dev response. No
hoursPlayed: you cannot. I tried that many times and the orders were ignored by my units. They never focused fired. Either it was a bug or another missing feature that should have been in game. Both of which are unacceptable for the price you pay and for it being a released game. I cannot test this again since I have recived a refund for the game. Now I wish I had recorded my gameplay. I'll do that next time."

reviewText:
I wish there was a so-so rating, neither thumbs up nor thumbs down. But since we have only the two choices, and I am requesting a refund, it has to be thumbs down.

As a huge fan of TA/CC/BT, SupCom, FA, SupCom 2 (yes 2), Sins of a Solar Empire w/some xpacs (multiplayer saves! yes thank you!), and a mild fan of PA and PA/Titans, I was super excited about this game and wanted to love it. Bought two licenses to play w/my son (whom I have played all of the above games with).

We read most of the manual waiting for the game to download and then we played through the tutorial.

Sadly, this game doesn't come close to the above games. It has some elements from previous games but doesn't do them as well.

If you are a fan of the games I listed, especially the TA/SupCom series, read the manual before you buy (I don't know if that's possible).

The game felt sluggish for me and was missiong keybind controls I've grown used to (adjusting game speed from keys, selecting units of the same type from a key, etc.)

Also read the developer roadmap. If I had done those 2 things I would not have bought the game. Maybe by the end of 2016 this game might be close to as fun as some of the other games listed. Right now I'm not sure what niche it fills.

On my i7 920 w/12GB DDR (yes 12GB, triple channel mobo) w/a GTX960 (on which all of the other games just fly and look much better - except PA - that game's graphics are terrible) the game was sluggish and the UI was particularly unpleasant to use.

Also played on an i5-3570 w/32GB RAM and a HD6870.

Some things I'd like to see:

1. Meaningful unit name (Artemis, Apollo, Nemesis, Zeus, Fury really convey no information).
2. More unit and structure variety (kbots were lighter, a little cheaper, faster to build, moved faster than vehicles, their engineers built things slower, but they had some variants that you couldn't get in vehicles in TA/supcom). They weren't redundant units, they really did bring something different to the table. How about a navy? Or gunships, or strategic bombers for air - here we get a fighter and a bomber. More variety in defensive structures.
3. Useful strategic icons
4. More keybinds (select all units of same type, control game speed, etc.)
5. Control of the camera angle. Sometimes you want a top down view, sometimes at an angle, sometimes close to the ground.
6. Experimentals or meaningful research. +% damage, +% health is a start but shows lack of creativity. Camera shells, direct fire artiller, legs on ships, long range artiller, gunships, etc. those are all cool creative upgrades that require creativity and more work in balancing but make the game way more interesting.
7. Much more responsive UI. This really shouldn't be so sluggish on these PCs.

Overall, my opinion is if I pay $50 for a new RTS, it really needs to be at least as much fun as the ones I've played before, and have at least most of the features/capabilities of its much older predecessors. I mean you have so much prior art to be inspired from, you get to stand on the shoulders of giants that have come before.

I like Stardock and hope they do well with this game, but we're requesting refunds. May not get them because we left the tutorial paused while we had dinner so it logged 3 hours played which is past the 2 hr limit for refunds, but we'll see. Definitely not worth $50 a pop for me at this moment.

reviewText:
I will give it a recommendation as I appreciate all the work that has gone into this game, however it comes at a cost, the game is nothing more than a DX12 tech demo, the campaign is a 30 day afterthought. If you are coming into this with a C&C campaign mindset I am afraid you are going to be very disappointed.

Skirmish and MP is where its at but because of the terrible bland environments and all units look similar, boring buildings and so on I can see it becoming boring fast.
I was really looking forward to the end result, I have been playing beta skirmish for a while and enjoyed it but unfortunately this game is released at least a year too soon and I can imagine many gamers right now are pretty angry and probably feel slightly mislead.

Although I recommended the game I will break it down:
Campaign 2/10
Skirmish & MP  6/10
Sound 8.5/10
Re-playability 7.5/10
Graphics 8/10

UPDATE:
The devs have promised a better campaign in the coming months, WE WILL SEE..

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This comes with a slight health warning. It's early release!
How often do we hear that particular line of reason in Beta? Ashes is very good to look at and, in terms of campaign and story very unfinished, as you would expect. It suffers from comparison with supreme commander which, given its development, might be unfair.
My alarm comes from something very basic: the AI engine. I don't think it is up to scratch because it's just a swarm game, there's no finesse to it and no opportunity to outmanouvre the enemy. As with so many games of this genre the game is made difficult by allowing the AI to cheat in resourcing and exploiting the fact that the human eye can't encompass the whole map but the computer can.
That said, I didn't mind paying the reduced price and have mildly enjoyed the graphics, sound and familiar feel. Lets hope it will get better with less linear mapping and more tactical gameplay. If there was a button for yes and no I'd use that, it just about gets a cautious thumbs up.

I have down graded the game. It's not going to get better, in spite of what I say above, because the the AI is useless. Plyed on the beginner setting it's absurdly easy, raise one level and the AI goes into cheat mode. I haven't even bothered with normal. It's possible to be defeated even if you own 3/4 of the resources on the map and outnumber the enemy; one enemy dreadnought easily destroys two of your own even if you're supported by repair facilities and fixed defences. The AI can also attack on several fronts and a human can't keep up because your own forces don't have AI behavior. Even in a narrow defile your troops ignore an enemy who can get past and cause havoc in your rear territory.

The game is big on eye candy and low on good design.
voteText: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Interesting game
Needs Polish

All dialogue in the campaign is text-based, and jumps up in front of your screen in the most invoncenient times, stopping you from doing anything until you've either read it or hastilly skipped through it. And if you were panning about the battlefield when this happened, the camera glitches and continues to pan in that direction indefinitely until you hit that key again.

Due to the text-based dialogue, I found it incredibly difficult to empathise with the characters, as I was too busy commanding my army to have much time for reading.

The game also seems to take forever to load into the main menu, but is then fast to load everywhere else, another gripe I have is that the volume slider for the music also controls the volume for the cutscenes. So if you are like me, and you turn the music down or off while you play, you will have little or no sound in your cutscenes.

The difficulty curve is strange, I'm on the second last campaign mission now, and I appear to be stuck. I've played against and beaten mutiple opponents in previous missions, but now it is me and my 2 allies vs 1 enemy, and we just get steamrolled every time. It doesn't help that the guide character tells you to build bombers and just attack the enemy HQ, a tactic which I assume would have worked in a previous version of the game, before the bombers were nerfed, but as it is, it's completely ineffective and all the time and resources you put into those bombers only to see them wiped out, means you will likely have to restart the mission.

Based on my experience, I would not recommend this game in it's current state, there are a lot of issues that I don't feel should have made it into the production version, I assume and hope they will be fixed in future patches.

I have not played the multiplayer, only the campaign.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I cannot reccomend this game, for this price, at this time.  It is currently a skirmish editor and very little else.  It promises of  releasing in the near future a 'campaign' across planets....best to wait and see if that makes this game unique.  Otherwise this game has the same tactics and units as every other RTS since C&C.  It does support gargantuan sized armies and this is why the specs may be a lead weight for some rigs.  In my opinion I doubt the campaign will do little more than story stitch a series of lifeless maps.  The game would benefit greatly with maps that have combat effecting terrain.

The Early Adopters gamble that all this will pay out when the missing features do show up, seem to be the only excitement in this game.

UPDATE:  Better maps now exist.  Terrain has elevation, not sure if there are true benefits.  Units dont seem to get stuck or fail to obey movement commands.  Better.  Units are more interesting and do feel updated vs the older TA types.  Improved and prettier than TA, but still TA.  Getting much closer to a YES!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review is for the games current condition. (28/2/16).

I was really looking forward to this game. When it went down to £20 (-50% off) I had to buy it.

I was expecting a relatively good beta mainly because of reviews read and the price. I was a bit disappointed.

The game itself looks quite ugly on the highest settings. For some reason I couldn't achieve the high resolution appearance of the screenshots.

Scrolling the map is stuttery. The maps themselves look quite messy. The location of resources is a bit naff although I can see why they placed them there. I think it's down to the poor design of maps.

I was expecting a ton of units, even for this stage, but there is very few apparently. There is also very limited research to be done.

All in all I was disappointed. I would not recommend buying this game now and definitely not for £40. I find that price outrageous.

With that said, I will keep an eye on it. If I find my main concerns are addressed, I will likely purchase this game as it has a great deal of potential.

reviewText:
TLDR: The game is fun in the beginning but gets old fast..the game is a bit rigid and optimal strategies are very limited. UI is antique.

The good
*Fullfills the fantasy of large sci-fi armies clashing together with glorious lasers and futuristic weapons
*Awesome graphics and performance
*Easy to learn
*Cool Soundtrack
*Dreadnoughts

The bad
*Gets old fast, standard build orders and once you figure out the strongest units you'll have a set build every single game
*Tutotial with text boxes in 2016!
*Campaign is lackluster with repetitive missions and texts for dialogue instead of voice acting, feels low-production
*Units behavior in an army is sub-optimal
*My biggest problem is with the UI which feels really old:
-tooltips are lacking, and there are no tooltips for already built units..I need a way to know what type of unit the enemy has, like is it artillery or heavy or whatever
-army control is limited
-macro tools are sub-optimal, cannot zoom out the entire map like supreme commader or at least switch to a strategic view with the whole map
-ability to form armies but no formations and no option to adjust the direction the army is facing
-finding info about multiple dreadnoughts in the same army is almost impossible..
-selecting units of a specific type, like air/land units only or long range only in such a macro game is a needed feature.
-cannot easily add new units to existing groups.
-renaming existing control groups into new numbers is buggy
-patrolling more than one point takes the stupidist routes
-and so many other details that needed a lot more polish to bring the game's UI to 2016

reviewText: I am dissapointed, I have purchased all of Stardock games. This time I had hoped ashes would be a hit. This game is priced as a triple A title of almost $50 when in reality it should be about $15. reviewText:
Huge fan of SOASE and RTS games in general. Some of my earliest memories as a kid were playing Red Alert and it never stopped from there. My favorite games include the Total War franchise, starcraft, company of heroes, civilization, age of empires, dawn of war, command and conquer, etc. I don't mind text exposition, or not being able to tell frigate type 1 from frigate type 2, so how could I not like this game?

Difficulty.

I've got thousands upon thousands of hours in RTS games, yet just the Normal difficulty completely wipes the floor with me. It's not even close. Campaign, I got to the 4th planet in Chapter I, then lost 11 times in a row. So I decided to try the skirmish mode, 1v1, 2v2, same thing. Complete curbstomp. That's not a bad thing if we were talking about an 'Very Hard' difficulty, but not normal.


I hyped this game up a lot to my friends who had never played a Stardock game, then had to turn around and tell them not to bother because I know they would never beat the AI in a single match with their lesser RTS experience. Hell, I can barely do it. Really wanted to love this like I did SOASE 1/2, but it feels like a puzzle to be solved and not a video game.

Recommendation: Scale down the AI difficulty.

reviewText:
I swear every time a new RTS is announced I get hyped and then the game proceeds to be a huge disappointment. Ashes of the Singularity is no different.
Pros:
-Large scale battles very reminiscent of games like Total Annihilation and Supreme Commander.
-Pretty good music
-Map regions are an interesting concept and are implemented quite well.
Cons:
-Not much variety in terms of different units and structures.
-Everything looks the same.
-Textures and models looks terrible unless you're zoomed out
-The game looks like it came straight out of 2008 yet requries top of the line hardware to run at a decent framerate.

In it's current state the game is worth nowhere near it's $60 price tag. I'm hoping the developers can up the visual fidelity of the game or at least better optimize it. Personally I'd wait for the game's price to drop to $30 or less before buying, and even then I'd only recommend it to the most hardcore RTS fans.

reviewText:
This game is nothing like Supreme Commander, its very limited.  If you like Starcraft, you might like this.  If you like Dawn of War online multiplay pvp, you might like this.

But its nothing like Supreme Commander...

With tiny maps.  Tiny Scale, and while trying to have players not have to micro, needs more micro then ever when it comes to controling points, because thats the only way you win.

Its more like Zone Control if anything.  Its clearly meant to try and appeal to those of us that love TA and FA, but its a complete failure in that department.

Bearly physics based projectiles, from what i can tell they arn't.  A lot more like Supreme Commander 2, with worse gameplay.

The game is about capping points all around the map, forcing Zonecontrol" and not allowing for any real tactics.  You either get good at this one type of play
date:
or you lose.

It doesn't allow for players to think up unique builds or play styles like FA does.

If you are one of those people (like me) that loves TA
hoursPlayed: you wont like this game."

reviewText: 1. The campaign is a tutorial.  I understand that games have to include tutorials so first timers know how to play. Fine.  AotS takes the tutorial to a whole new level.  First of all, you can select Tutorial" from the main menu and learn all about the game.  But if you choose to play the campaign
date: your game will be repeatedly inturrupted by an illegible text box that prevents you from actually playing the game until you click enought times to dismiss it (meanwhile your opponent is still active).  This is infuriating as it will actually pull you to another area on the map as you are trying to build up your defenses or attack your opponent.  What's worse is that in late game
recommended:
you will recieve tutorial messages about units and structures that YOU HAVE ALREADY USED IN PREVIOUS MISSIONS!!! Love how I've already annihilated an enemy with dreadnaughts only to have a tutorial about dreadnaughts on the second to last mission...

2. Loading a save game.  You actually have to quit the game to load a previous save.  WTF!?!

3. Bugs.  I can't count the number of times that I've have restart a mission or load a save from over an hour before because all of a sudden my factories couldn't produce units or my engineers progress was frozen or an enemy dreadnaught just couldn't be hit.  I got so tired of this happening that I thought I'd enjoy myself more by writing a review...

While not totally game breaking
hoursPlayed: I also find that my speed settings tend to fluctuate.  I'll set the game speed  to "slow" so I can  order a bunch of engineers around
voteText: only to have it set itself back to "normal" or even "fast" when I'm being attacked.\n\nBeing able to hold Shift to assign multiple orders is pretty much a staple of the RTS genre

The maps are claustrophobic; full of ravines and mountains to channel your troops into useless columns as they march towards their deaths.  Not conducive of the large scale battles that were promised by developers (and achieved by SupCom). Your units move rediculously slow through most terrain
commentsCount: but God forbid you try to climb a hill.  I found myself speeding the game up just to get over a little hump (BTW all the units hover! WTF?!)\n\n5.We tell you how to play.  This is my biggest gripe about this game.  The developers had  an idea of how this game should be played
column16: and we're all beholden to it.  All of these stupid restrictions during missions: Oh
column17: all of a sudden I get no amplifiers? Hey
column18: why not arbitrarily just take out ground defenses? Done!\n\nNo Workshop?  Really? Is it pride? Did you create the perfect game and no one can mess with it?  SoaSE was modded and was great!  WTF Stardock?"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are plenty of other comments talking about game play and bugs, I want this review to focus on the PVP.

There is no pvp.

Custom matches are utterly nonexistent. Ranked match maker puts you up against bots. At first i thought they were just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who wouldnt gl hf. 4 games i have played, 4 bots i have fought. Generically named opponents who employ the same strategies at the same pace every game. The ranking boards have about 300 players. This is a very, very, quiet game in terms of player activity which is a shame because the game is quite fun. I would rather sit in queue for 15 minutes looking for a human than be put against a damn bot after 3 minutes of waiting.

I understand this is an EA beta at the earliest of stages, but if your looking for anything but bug testing the game against AI opponents i would stay far away until the game is much farther along in development.

pros:
No discernable bugs
Well optimized: 1080p with 390 & fx8320 @ 60+fps
Assymetrical races

cons:
Impossible to find a human opponent

I check up on this game every couple of months and will be rewriting this review as the game develops.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I got this game on impulse. I also broke my rule of not every buying early access games. I regret both.

This game certainly has potential. The gameplay seems like it could be really interesting if expanded, but right now it's monotonous. There's also barely a difference between the two factions, as far as I can tell. You don't micro in this game, and it was designed that way, so I'll leave the judgement of that to you. That leaves the macro mechanics to differentiate the factions. And boy, the macro mechanics are pretty much identical.

At this early access stage, it's also missing so much and doesn't feel performant. The lighting quality is abyssmal for the amount of graphics power this game uses. I run a GTX 970 overclocked, the game averages <30fps on the benchmark at max settings. I get better frames in Rome II, and that game looks stunning compared to this. Hell, Dota looks stunning compared to this. There is a problem with either the video memory management or the input-to-output chain, causing some noticable lag. But this is early access, so I'm sure they'll fix it. Eventually.

The game's got potential. Don't buy this until it's actually released.

reviewText:
Ashes is your basic run-of-the-mill standard RTS. That is it has very little to do with actual strategy and more to do with just spamming the same units. But this isn't always a bad thing on its own; After all there are a lot of other areas where a game can fail to be good and just end up mediocre.

But Ashes has a good deal of mediocrity to it:
-lacluster and blocky units
-low levels of detail
-underwhelming graphics
-only a handfull of different units
-Stale gameplay
-the list goes on...

Unfurtunately this game has some things that work to make it more on the bad side as well such as its horrendously high requirements for such low levels of performance... higher level GPUs are needed if you want a decent frame rate and nothing in the game warrants such requirements. I mean the units are low poly-count, low detail and weapons fire is as underwhelmin as it could look in addition to maps that aren't anything special. So why does it have such high needs?

The crashes, OMG the crashes. Good luck getting it past the tittle screen.

They said this was a succesor to su[reme commander and they lied completely. There's nothing here that gives you any sence of emense units or lots of them since the economy barely allows you to build anything and the number of structures/units is a joke. No shields, no stealth, just your basic land and air units; and i do mean basic units... Even the so called dreadnaughts are pitiful, barely more powerfull than cruisers. (what happened to everything between cruiser and dreadnaught anyway?) There is no naval side to this at all either so your units are:

-2 air
-3 small land
-4 medium land
-3 large land

Base defences are worthless as well, they have no health and only tickle their targets. But that can be mitigated by using units to defend.
They also lied about having thousands of units. Just outright lied.
And another damning element is the fact that you cannot under any cercumstance direct your units to fire on any specific unit in an enemy's army. All you can do is have them attack the army as a whole and watch as they spread the damage as much as possible instead of focusing on the dangerous parts. :(

Anyway, this game isn't a completely bad one but it won't give you a challenge, it won't wow you, and it wont impress you in the slightest. It will bore you very quickly as well. Nothing about it hasn't been done, and been done better, before.

So do I recommend it? No, it's not worth more than a few dollars honestly but it might entertain you for a little while.

reviewText:
Game has potential, But still many bugs.
Can't recommend it(yet), Constant freezing issues and random game crashes.
Graphics are great but gameplay is quite annoying, Having your controls completely taken over by computer telling mission story at the worst possible time, Can't skip it which is frustrating.
Game seems to be a rush to resources first, You can't turtle this game if you are the type that likes to build up base first then you will get overwhemed by computer AI regardless of what difficulty you select.
Some of the later abilities are too over powered and also the main dreadnought ships are way too slow.
By the time you turn them around to defend your base the computer has already wiped out half your base.
Being able to teleport engineers and units to different areas of the map is ridiculous in my opinion, Ruins the game and turns it into a rush fest.
I give developers credit for DX 12 implementation and the game certainly has potential, but I do not recommend spending your hard earned on it just yet until major freezing/crashing issues are addressed, Maybe pick it up next time it goes on sale.

reviewText:
I will admit that this game has the potential to be phenominal.  A few major grievances I have are of a fairly specific nature, the kind that may or may not matter to you.  I'll just run down a simple pros and cons list and you can judge for yourself.

Pros:
*Every unit has a place

*Every building has a place

*DirectX12 graphics allow for some of the best visual fidelity I have seen in years for a strategy game
Maps are grand in scale, with a unique Line of Sight Fog of War system that lends to the techy future this game tries to convey

*The use of actual strategy comes with fantastic rewards, high ground is in fact very hard to take, and very easy to hold.  Sightlines are paramount to success.  You can tell they put a lot of thought into how to make sure you think about what you do before you do it.


Cons:
Campaign lacks intrique - Text dialogue mixed with no real" cinematics makes it feel like a string of custom games more than a story worth re-telling

SupCom light.

There's no VO. All text.
I bet they'll charge for DLC mission packs.
Stardock loves DLC.

Apart from that, not much to say. If you've played Supreme Commander you've played this game so nothing new to see here.

reviewText:
I've been starved for a good RTS game, but sadly this one didn't satisfy my appetite.  There's not a lot of depth or strategy to the game.  The good ol' tank rush is alive and well.  The graphics are ok, although a bit amateurish.  In fact, that adequately describes the game in general.  Not much of a story, and when it's told it's through a mix of unbalanced audio and text.  And the annoying thing about the text is that you have to click to move passed it.  So if a text sequence shows up during a battle, it can be quite frustrating since you have to quickly click through the messages in order to interact with your units again.

The game is also quite buggy.  Audio issues, armies not forming correctly, control groups getting unassigned at random, lockups and crashes, just to name a few.  Needs a little more QC.

If you're looking for a good RTS game, keep looking. A Supreme Commander replacement this ain't.
voteText: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I was really pulled in by the possible story, the action from the video tempted me. After buying the game I regret every moment spending the amount of cash they are asking for. This is your basic RTS and even that has been boiled down to its simplist form.

The units do not level, and combat seems too zerg like. Game play/stratagey is good, but keeping an eye on all your factories and stuff just to keep pumping out units seems boring.

There are better RTS's out so I really recommend not spending the $50 and save that for a real game where that money could be used.

reviewText:
Although I really want to say this game is good I just can't.  The entire game is just an attack move fest and the way resources work is just silly.  The best way I can describe it is they took Sins of the Solar Empire, removed the gravity well mechanic, tech tree, and planet development and called it a new game.

Coming from a game like Starcraft this has the tactical depth of a kiddie pool.   Maybe someone who wants a more casual RTS would enjoy it, but for me it just gets boring.  The only real strategy to speak of is army positioning and choosing which front to push along.

Buy it on sale, I bought during early access for $25, wait for it to drop at least that low.

reviewText:
I am not normally one to write reviews for games, but this time I feel the need to express what I consider a very negative side about the game.

I concerns the UI scaling.
If you have a monitor that only supports a resolution anywhere between the minimum requirement and 1920x1080, the UI will only scale to a maximum of 80%, first at 1920x1080 do you get 100% scale.
This can make it difficult for anyone with less than optimal eyesight to be able to read any text on the screen, and no amount of editing the config file or tuning windows settings will help , the game overrides or ignores any and all such changes.

As someone who is near sighted and uses glasses this makes any text on the screen too small for me to comfortably read due to the distance from my monitor.
I use a TV as a monitor and have a distance of 140 cm to my monitor, this means that in order for me to read the text on the screen I need to either lean forward into the screen to see the text, or strain my eyes to be able to read, which leads to headaches after a while

After trying to discuss the matter with the developers on their forums(not steam) they give the impression of being less than interested in doing anything about it , but more interested just sweeping the issue aside rather than listen to the feedback they get and try to do something about it.

From what little I have been able to play it seems like a good game and I would like to give ita good review, but because of the issues above I cannot recommend this game.

reviewText: This game is already outrageously hard, but it's so buggy it makes it nearly impossible. Units can't find their way anywhere without you micro-managing them, the pathfinding is awful; units don't obey commands, I've issued an attack or retreat command so many times just for my units to die disobeying them. Units and structures are constantly vanishing into the ground so I can't even click on them if I can even remotely see them there. The couple of times I've almost beat a level the game just crashes altogether, losing all my progress. This game is a total mess. I mostly bought it at the prospect of finally having a game in DirectX 12 but as it turns out not only is the performance incredibly bad in DirectX 12 (vs 11) but even more visual glitches occur making this game almost unplayable. Wait till it comes down in price and/or gets patched, it's not worth playing in its current form.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Chance to start a game is 25%: 3 of 4 tries it fails to load. Dx12 version does not start at all - crashes every load attempt.
8 Gb of RAM is not enough to even launch a game! It's just ridiculous. Overall performance is very bad.

About gameplay:
Could be interesting, but there is no much different strategies. You can do small, medium, large land units and air units, That's all... There is no devastating artillery, intelligence, nucear weapons etc. Only stupid mass units production and  resource points rush, Gameplay is very simple and repetitive. Hotkey set for managing groups is incomplete and annoying.

Early Access Review

This game was really not well optimized and could barely run on my PC. On medium or lower settings it looked attrocious with missing meshes and animations just non existant. This is one of the least optimized games I've ever seen, as I do have a high end PC.

Gameplay was simplistic and tedious. Expanding and basebuilding is torture, and only at pre-defined locations on the map with these unnecesary yellow lines everywhere. I like some of the concepts. I still prefer Supreme Commander which was a lot better than this game in every single way.

reviewText:
Originally reviewed this for early access
But since I was asked to give thoughts on the full version...

It feels exactly the same.
It's simplistic, good looking and that's about it.
Do you want an RTS that doesn't require much thought and supports DX12? There you go.

The first half of the game is rushing to get resources, the next half is taking the other player(s) resources and building an army big enough to surpass metal gear.

Let's critique the selling points together, shall we? Let's go!

1. Wage a War Across an Entire World"
If you wanna over-sell playing on one map at a time
date: then sure let's go with that.\n\n2. "Command Unique Units
hoursPlayed: Orbitals
voteText: and Abilities"\nBuilders
helpfulPercent: small fighters
votesHelpful:
medium fighters and large fighters. Totally unique. Let's not forget the 2 factions
and the amazingly pointless orbital abilities.

3. "Experience a powerful
votesTotal:
Non-Cheating AI Engine"
If you're going to make a skirmish only game
let's make sure the A.I is good in case you can't find a match.

4. "Battle with Friends in Multiplayer Matches"
Again
votesFunny: it's skirmish only so that's an obvious choice.\n\n5. "Claim Victory with Strategy
commentsCount: not Speed"\nYet you're rushing to get resources
column16: there's no strategy in having a thousand more\nunits than the guy you're playing with but hey
column17:
this game has no real selling points.

6. "Encounter Mysterious New Threats in Ascendancy Wars"
This is the worst of them. We're all familiar with scenarios in RTS and TBS games but saying
we're going to encounter mysterious new threats is just ridiculous.


Also the other reviewers raving about how the units micro for you brings up the summary of this review.
Get it if you're a filthy casual that doesn't know how to micro and loves l33t graphix."

reviewText:
This game is garbage!

!!Unit control is almost nonexistent!!
When I try to select one unit to move it back because of damage the game selects five other units or more.
When I send a group of units to attack, half of the group runs the other direction and does some stupid dance of some kind before finally moving forward. When I right click to give a fast move command the game thinks I want to move the camera so the unit never gets the move command, and there is nowhere to change key bindings!

Playing this game, I ROFLStomp the AI simply by building a crap-ton of units fast, no unit micro needed (because you cannot) and no regard to unit type (no real counters or balancing).

TL:DR:
No unit control.
No key binding options.
Crappy unit pathfinding.
No balance or true unit counters.
stupid AI.


This crap game might be worth $10, what a waste of $40, stay away.

reviewText:
March 31, 2016

I waited until release in order to give a fair review. This game runs extremely slow. 1st mission with one scout and one artillery unit, just trying to draw a selection box is slow. I am getting 5-15 frames per second. Edit April 3 2016; After setting nvidia control panel to performance, the game ran at an acceptable rate.

My rig:

Asus CG8480
i7-3770k
quad core
3.5 GHz
16 GB Ram
GTX660

Believe this or not but the game is using text based naritives, with no voice. You read snippets of text and 'press next. The Camera will not hold it's tilt when you zoom. This was mentioned many many and many times. Day one launch and the problem is still there.

Because I gave my honest feed back
date:
I have been banned from the ashes forums. This is the message I received when I tried to post;

"You have been permanently banned from all Ashes of the Singularity discussions.
You were banned by a Ashes of the Singularity developer.
Reason: "You've overstayed your welcome."

This coming from a  developer who states that he listens to the community. All I asked for was a camera that kept its tilt when you zoom. I get kicked forever  because I thought it was really cheap to have a game with no cut scences and a text based message with no voice in mission.

The units could be more diverse. No infantry. Units just float. The maps are void of anything. Its just a blob vs blob war. Planes circle like helicopters.

This game is about a 4.7-5.3/10
recommended: (edit 3 April 2016: new score 6.3-6.7 see below in comments). My score takes a big hit because I expect a single player that reflects the intro video. If the dev decides to go half way by skimping out on single player
hoursPlayed: he should say so in advance. People don't buy potential and this feels unfinished and rushed.\n\nThe resource system mechanics are needlessly repetative when developing a node which doesn't add to gameplay. Advertising is focused too much on showing graphic effects on high end machines. Instead of seeing gameplay mechanics in videos
voteText: we see blobs of flashy lights. Game plays like blob warfare with little player involvement other than trying to get a general balanced blob to move forward and capture another node. Looks good in videos to see flashy lights on a high end machine but playing it is bland. Get more nodes and push your blob forward.\n\nI have been gaming forever. Since the CnC days. If you want a great RTS
helpfulPercent: play Act Of Aggression
votesHelpful: especially the Reboot edition which is now included for free."
