reviewText: Great in concept and presentation but falls short of expectations.\nI wanted to like this game, I really did.  I love Sins of a Solar Empire and I figured Stardock would do a great job with this too but honestly I don't see what all the hype is about.  Sins is a much better game and this game just has nothing that other games don't and it's even lacking in some areas I find.  I mean the win condition of the control the resource node" is nice but this seems to be just a spamfest of whoever pumps out the most units the fastest or whoever gets the first leveled up dreadnaught.  Speaking of dreadnaughts all you really need is a group of them and you're good
date: kind of kills the whole strategy thing when all you have to do is build the big units and you're alright.  There could at least be a little more variety in them instead of only having 3 each.  I mean take Sins for instance
recommended: with few exceptions you really do want all of the capital ships in a fleet and no matter how many you spam there's still great use for a lot of the smaller craft even though they die a lot.  But in Ashes the smaller units just get sneezed on by dreads and poof they're gone
hoursPlayed: not even a point.\n\nBut let's talk about the selling point... massive scale battles with thousands of units and dreadnaughts that are 57 miles long woo!  Just no
voteText: it doesn't matter how big the unit is in the game world when it's half an inch on your screen and the map size is 20 feet. (just random numbers thrown in there)  And thousands of units?  Why when a group of 6-8 dreads will blow up basically everything?  Sure you can't put them in an "army" so they won't benefit from each others auras and what not but still... the difference in unit classes is too much.  And back on the massive scale thing.. there have been other games that do the massive scale better
helpfulPercent: in my opinion Sins is one of them.\n\nSo how about base building?  I kind of like what they did with the "grid" or "network" of resources but at the same time I feel like it's more of a downer.  It's a neat new thing sure but in practice I don't really like it.  I also found the PHC repair bays to be slightly over powered
votesHelpful: especially when you can drop one or several of those "temporary" railgun turrets next to one and they never expire (because "temporary" in this case means it loses health until it's dead) and my gosh those things own.\n\nI really can't recommend this game
votesTotal: especially at the current price of $40 USD.  I feel like maybe for $10... but not really because again
votesFunny: nothing here that other games don't do better and nothing new holding me to it."

reviewText:
I am a veteran RTS player...  Total Annihilation, Command and Conquer, Homeworld, Supreme Commander, Demigod, Kohan, Sins of a Solar Empire, and on and on.

This game plays very much like a dumbed down version of Supreme Commander.  The node system while interesting didn't expand strategic decisions.  The node system just seemed to limit where you could move on the map.  If you have control of some areas where there is only one route in and out, those rear areas are safe from attack and you can just build defenses further forward.

The Titan units rule the battlefield and are interesting, but sadly you can obtain them within a couple of minutes.  Contrary to what other people describe as a more casual game my experience seemed fast and clicky.  The strategy boiled down to expand quick.  Find a bottleneck.  Defend there (defenses are weak and drop quickly) and build Titans as quick as possible.  Send large army forward to roll.  Keep adding in more reinforcements.  Keep your army together.  If you split your forces and they meet up with a bigger army they will be gone within 30 seconds or so.  There is no chance for adjusting once you commit to battle.

If you like a simpler strategy game that moves at a good clip and lets you engage with a lot of units then this is the game for you.  If you want something deeper, I recommend going back to Forged Alliance.

reviewText:
The only ashes are from this game crashing and burning.

It's not actually a really bad game, it's just undercooked, underbudgeted and slightly too bland. There's only two semi-identically playing factions and barren, lifeless maps that consist of little else than height maps and noise textures.

There's a single player campaign, but it's not very well produced and doesn't even have voice acting - in 2016!

For a base price of 40€ I expected more and I expected better production values. (I'm glad that I didn't pay 40€ as I got it with a big discount).

The core gameplay is OK and it can be fun to play, but the overall package is very lacking in polish.

Not recommended unless you're really, really sure you'll like what you get.

reviewText:
This game is not good.

It's not bad by any means, but it's simply too expensive to justify what it brings to the table
I have listed below the pro's and con's.

Pro's
-The game looks amazing on highest graphics settings

-Massive battles

-A solid economy and build area system

-Air units

Con's
-No naval units

-There is no micro (micro is managing individual units to have them do better, for example, by dodging slow artillery shells)

-Getting the game to run on highest settings is VERY difficult

-If you use nvidia, don't even buy this, the game is unplayable on nvidia

-The UI and camera controls are clunky and difficult to use

-Multiplayer community is tiny, finding a game is very difficult and requires a willingness to wait a good 30 mins for a game

-No superweapons

-Very unbalanced, bomber snipes run rampant and you need, I kid you not, more than 10 AA emplacements to stop them

-You can't defend, It's aggressive aggressive aggressive with this. If you like to turtle up and slowly conquer territory this isn't going to be a fun game for you

-All the effects look very sameish. They all look like glowy dots of different colors. It's like looking at a neon ball pit.

And lastly, the pricing.
This game is WAY WAY WAY WAY WAY too expensive to be worth even looking at.
At 20$ on {LINK REMOVED}♥♥♥.com this game is still more expensive than Supreme Commander:Forged Alliance at $15, which has a huge community called forged alliance forever, looks better, has more diversity, more mechanics, is more fleshed out, has micro, and runs on a toaster.
At the astonishing $50 full price this game is more expensive than even Planetary Anihilation:Titans at $40 which has not only innovative mechanics like BATTLES IN ORBIT but also seperate planets you can fight across as well as micro and all that mentioned above. Titans won't run on a toaster, but at least if you have an nvidia card you can still play it.

This game is OK-ISH but there are much better games out there for a FRACTION of the cost.

Final Verdict:
Steer clear of this and maybe pick it up for $5 during the summer sale.

reviewText:
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Second update:
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
So update: Did anything change that I found so annoying? Sadly no.

Graphics: Still need to restart the game if you change anything at all. Even things like AA etc.. which really only takes a context restart. The problem here (guesstimating since I don't see the source code) is that I suspect the graphics code is integrated with game logic. So if you change anything, and a restart is needed, the logic breaks because it too needs a restart. The solution here is to move the graphics engine to a separate thread, away from the main game logic. Then they can recreate the context to their hearts content. I have no idea how possible it is to move at this stage, it might very well be impossible due to the sheer volume of rewrite. If so, I hope they take this away as a lesson learned for the future. Keep in mind that I am talking about DX12. I haven't tested the non dx12 version, and frankly I can't be bothered at this stage.

Sluggishness: Still remains, but like I said, the game itself is good. It is just so annoying with these other aspects that playing something that have the response time of playing a game remotely across the planet, simply is too distracting. I won't say much here about it, more further down.

Font: The blurriness because font is scaled, rather than native for the chosen resolution makes the text barely readable at lower resolution. Which you will need for performance (below)
For the devs: Choose a table of font resolutions, so that for low res you might have 6x4 pixels font, higher 8x5, 12x8 and so on. So that a series of resolutions up to a certain level get a higher native font resolution. Set the scales so that the font doesn't appear too little, or too large for the range of resolutions. It takes a while to get that table, but it is well worth it. So please do that.

Performance: (Relates to sluggish above) It still is very hungry. For what reason I have no idea. I could compare with my own project, but it would serve little purpose. I am just very curious what they are doing that consumes this massive amount of performance. Because it seems it doesn't matter what resolution, or graphical settings I set. It is still massively slow. I have a GTX 780 which can play pretty much anything over or at 60 fps. Certainly if I set the settings right. But this?? I don't know. I wish I could say something that could help these guys getting this performance right, but it is so long now.. I don't know.

There are also typical issues like low angle shadow artifacts, but those exist in pretty much any game. etc.. I consider those minor, and wont bring them up.

So there it is.. the update really doesn't change much of the things I find so annoying that it detracts from having fun playing the game. Which is terrible, I find the story interesting, and I really would like to enjoy playing it. But i just cannot see past the issues above. Because I certainly wont fork out $$$ for a GTX Titan just to get playable performance.

Final words this time:

The game does seem interesting (story wise) the music is good and enjoyable, even if repetitive after a while. The graphics quality is really good, sound is good and if it were not for the things above, I would have very little bad things to say about it. If it had not been for the issues above, I would have happily recommended this game. But I cannot in good conscience recommend a game I honestly cant play properly.

reviewText: This is the biggest waste of money i have spent on a game in years. Slow, boring, and massively taxing on a computer yet the graphics are mediocre and the detail isn't that great. I tried to get a refund but steam wouldn't let me. I am an advanced PC gamer and I build my own PC's. I have a top of the line Z170 build with all the best hardware and I have never had an issue with any game until this one. Very mad about buying this, and even more mad I can't be refunded. This is honestly a more boring version of Star Wars, Empire at War. It's extremely similar in regards to resources and land control to win. I'm honestly going to delete this and play Empire at War again...which is a 10 year old game. Sad...just plain sad.

reviewText:
So let me start off by saying wow ... I had genuinely been looking forward to this game but holy h*ll.  I don't know it it is just me but the words chr*st f*ck were repeated at an alarming frequency.  The initial few campaign" levels do a good job at teaching you the basic mechanics of the game.  Unfortunately it is what I assume was the fourth mission/planet that everything goes to hell in a hand basket.

You start off with the knowledge that you must capture and hold some sort of special reactor/facility which in an of itself isn't bad.  Unfortunately the lack of resources pretty much make it a necessity to expand early on I found.  This is timed almost flawlessly by the first wave of hostile units and is almost guaranteed to outnumber your own force.  If you are lucky you can get by with minimal losses only to have the second and third waves barrelling down on your base.

If you can secure a position
date: it become tolerable until you are made aware that the enemy is producing air units.  This wouldn't be so bad if 1) the air units couldn't one shot your engineers and 2) the AA defense buildings you get could be built in time to catch the air units before they started bombing everything in your base.  Now your only real hope is the AA cruiser which trust me
recommended: don't really seem to cut it.  Now
hoursPlayed: if you can somehow survive that the enemy begins ramping up their attacks making the defensive buildings you had next to useless but don't worry
voteText: once everything seems hopeless you can build healing stations and medics
helpfulPercent:
great if you don't mind placing them away from front lines.

I managed to get to this point and genuinely believed that I might catch a break but it was here that all of my combat units decided to start ignoring orders.  You want us to retreat to the healing station so we don't die?  Better rush the enemy!  You want us to move to the right to counter the incoming enemy wave?  Let's chase down these remaining units to the left instead.  I checked to make sure that my mouse was actually clicking in the right place (it was) but my units just seemed determined to commit mass suicide out of range of my healing stations.

After restarting the mission six different times I can honestly say that this was far too painful a purchase.  Perhaps multiplayer or skirmishes will be simpler but I really don't care to find out.  I do not advise buying this game
votesHelpful:
rather I advise avoiding it and praying the company loses money.  Maybe then they will make a better game in the future.

I can not believe this game came out in 2016. Everything about it feels like it is 10+ years old. The sounds, the menus, the gameplay.

If I could describe this game in short, I would say: Clunky and uncomfortable.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I tried this game and I found it very lacking, in fact I made sure I got a refund on it before the time expired.
-There is no depth to this game, it feels almost like a MOBA with the way it forces you to follow the power line rather than a free build.
-No real strategy, its all about power building and being the first to get to the control points along the power lines.
-Graphics are nice, but that is it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nNot really a fan of the I win mechanic (criticality).  It's counter intuitive to a game that's trying to play on massive battles when you can just build a wall around yourself and farm points.  Add the option of turning that off and I'd be a lot more interested.  For now, don't recommend.

reviewText:
From what I can tell, AotS has done a great job of removing the excessive micromanagement replete in the RTS genre. But that micromanagement, ill-advised as it was, was still a gameplay element. Sadly, Stardock didn't think to replace that lost gameplay with anything else. Imagine playing Starcraft, but without unit management. All you'd be left to do is click factories and build units.

And that's what AotS is. Click the factory, build the unit, repeat.
But to be fair, I only did the tutorial-- which may not have provided me with a good look at the meat of the game. Alas-- the steam refund policy requires me to set this one aside without ever finding out. And that's hardly Valve's fault-- Stardock had their chance to show me what they had. And they either failed to show off their gameplay in 30 minutes, or they succeed in showing me they had no game for me to play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game isn't even in beta yet, so it gets alot of the standard gimmes and slack in-dev games expect.

That said, they are selling a PRE-BETA game...

PRE-BETA

For $50. It's just not worth it right now. Graphical issues, slow and non-responsive GUI, non-existent performance and optimization. My $2000 gaming machine (4.4Ghz 8 Core, 16 GB RAM, SSD) to it's knees. These things are all to be expected of a pre-beta game, and again, as a software developer myself, I understand why the game is in this state. But you absolutely should not be charging full price for a game that is so far out, so very incomplete.

That said, the concept looks excellent, unit design is impressive and unique and the mechanics of the game show promise. I really hope this one develops well and becomes something super fun, tight and polished.

reviewText:
*Alpha/Early Access review

Pros:
-Sort of like the Universe at War RTS (unit and building designs), but with less universe
-A bunch of maps in which to test out
-Multiplayer already implemented
-There's a benchmark test" to see how well your computer can run it
-More laser and missile smoke particles than there are stars in the entire Milky Way galaxy
-Unique sound and music design

*Note: Many improvements have been made per optimization since this review was made.

Cons:
-Only 2 factions in which to try (Early Access)
-Will need all of NASA computers to run it at maximum settings @60fps
-Maps are void of detail. Some trees and snow here and there (Final build has fixed this issue)
-Will need a few quantum computers to run it at maximum settings in 4k resolution @60fps
-Not a lot of content to warrant the current price. Too much pew pew with not a lot to do
-Running "benchmark test" at maximum settings then hearing screams of horror from your PC"

reviewText:
You probably want to find out about this game, and may have also played TA and SC, and are curious to see if this game is better, worse, or just different.  Here's some of the more important points to consider before buying or not.

The Good:

Amazing graphics:  Leading edge graphics.  If you want better graphics than this game has go watch the new Star Wars movie.

Orbitals:  You have a slew of possible orbital abilites you can call down" and use for a mydrid of offence
date: defence and support.  They add a lot more possible strategies.\n\nArmies:  You can set your groups to make "armies"
recommended: which move together at the same speed in formations
hoursPlayed: and change position and tactics based on the situation.\n\nAuto Build/Join:  My favorite Pro of the game.  While you have a group or amry highlighted
voteText: you can also access all possible unit's build menus
helpfulPercent: ordering what units you want built.  In addition (and this is the great part) when built
votesHelpful: those units travel to that army
votesTotal: and automatically join it.  I almost had a cigarette and laid back in bed when I first saw this happen.\n\nThe stately pace:  This may be a personal Pro
votesFunny: but this game is far more about thinking ahead and planning
commentsCount:
rather than twitch and reaction time.  No amount of ninja clicking will get you out of your bad decissions in this game.

The "Meh":

Bland
column16: lifeless maps:  While the unit graphis are amazing
column17: the terrain on maps are barren and bland.  You'll feel like your playing on a huge golf course or acers of tundra fields.\n\nThe UI:  The UI "works".  The game's mini map "works".  The lists of players
column18: stats
column19: units
column20: resoursces and scores "work".  But that's about all they do.\n\nUnit differenciation: You may have a lot of problems telling your units from an allie's units
column21: or worse
column22: telling an enemie's from yours if it's the same faction (until they fire on you).  The player color choices are subtle and a bit drab
column23: and unit types are sometimes very hard to identify until zoomed in.  There are no icons or symbols on units when you zoom out
column24: just dots.\n\nThe Campaign:  The campain is ok.  Barely just ok.  It's better than nothing.  A very basic story
column25: with chat boxes occationally interupting your game to text out a plot point.  The missions designs themselves are above average though
column26: and will give you a very good challenge at times.\n\nNo replays.  Enough said.  If you play a game of this with your friends
column28:
not watch it.

Attack/Defence:  You can use some of your "Quanta" to increase the Attack or Defence rating of units.  A throwback choice from old games which does nothing but cancel each other out.

The Bad'ish:

Less options & units:  You won't find many of the units or possible strategies that you would in TA or SC.  There are no shields; no artillery (except for dreadnaughts); no super units; no "super weapons that end the game unless you stop them"; no placement bonuses; and a below average selection of units to build.

Resource busywork:  There could be many dozens of resourse nodes to gain control of and mine on a map
column30: and they all need an engineer to be specically told to build each and every nodule.  This can become even more tedius and frustrating
column32: and you have to hunt down which are destroyed and then micro an engineer to rebuild each of them.\n\nBeta-like bugs:  There are still problems with the game that you would expect to see in a late stage beta.  It's often difficult (or impossible) to find a location to build a building
column33:
as there is no visual cue as to where it possible.  You just move your mouse round and round till the building turns from red to blue.  Groups and armies aften get mixed up; move in different directions; or freeze entirely.  Build cues for engineers often vanish after you spent a minute carefully placing them.  Lag and stuttering can plague a game even on the smallest maps and lowest video settings (even with solo play).

Well?:

This is one of those times when I lothe the Yes/No recommendation you are forced to choose when reviewing games on Steam.  If I could grade this game
column34: I would give it a C
column35: with a "crystal ball" potential of B in the future.  But there is no such choice.  So I will give a thumbs up (which I wish was a thumbs sideways) for now.\n\nFor more details
column36: there are untold amounts of YouTube videos to help you decide if you wish to see if this is the game for you or not."

reviewText:
This game would be a good buy but it keeps crashing.  I have a mid-grade pc that runs this game on ultra settings but it's inability to run a campaign game consistently without crashing and not being able to load back in to it is beyond frustrating.

Also, short campaign and lack of diversity between factions is a downside. 7/10


***Updated 5/21***

After noticing that admin had responded to my comment, I followed up with their advice have since updated my video driver and have no issues.  I'm honestly impressed with the feedback and suggestions from their staff/support.  That's a first for me and can't help but give 2 points back for sheer customer service and satisfaction.  I still believe that the campaign is a tad short but the MP is fun and makes up for it in the long run. 9/10

The price of this game is very High, for what it is. It is not unlike Supreme Commander 1 or 2, or even a sort of Command & Conquer. Maybe if it could run even faster.. Overall a OK game. It will get better with time. I know I have given this game a Thumbs Down, for now, I will change it to a Thumbs up, when it ticks all the right boxes later on. This game is getting there. At least this company is trying its best. Would be nice if there was some, more Powerful & Bigger flying craft or even some Super Weapons..I starting to find this game, a disapointing. Supreme Commander 2, is a better game. 17/05/16. I tried playing this game again, I am starting like even it even less. Wish I had not wasted my money.

reviewText:
While I am a fan of Stardock I have been leary of picking up Ashes of the Singularity.  The issue hasn't been with Stardock nor AotS but due to my feeling burnt by another similar game that also was trying to follow in the footsteps of the great classic RTS game Total Annilation.  That other game was Planetary Annliation.   I had such high hopes for it being the modern day Total Annliation revival.  However PA didn't fill that place like I had hoped.

Seeing AotS on sale elsewhere I decided it was finally time to give it a go.  While I wasn't keen on spending $40 and risking being disappointed, I could stomach $20.   I am glad that I did as the game is not only visually stunning but actually does feel like a competent successor to the classic Total Annilation series as well as Supreme Commander.

I must say that the game taxes my machine, a first gen i7 2.8ghz, 16Gb RAM and a GTX960.  The game comes with a benchmark tool and I average around 35-45fps in fairly large battles and around 25-30 in the huge battles.   However I have the graphics set all the way up so I am sure that with a slight bump down I could fair better but personally it is still okay even with the occasional studder.

All in all I recommend AotS.  Now the question is do I recommend it at the full asking price?  I guess that depends on how much you are wanting a game that fills the void left over the years by Total Annilation's aging.   For me I can say that I am sure I will get $20 worth of enjoyment, but if I had to do over again and pay the $40 price I think I would have to pass.  It is a decent game and nice to see actual RTS still alive outside MoBAs none the less.
